loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia B., wife of Z. I., is a mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Safia and her husband did not have the opportunity to pursue an education in their childhood, but they wish to give their children an opportunity to go to school and pursue their careers. All of her children are enrolled in a local school. Her husband is a auto-rickshaw driver as well as a baker at a local hotel. She would like to apply for a loan to pay the remaining two installments of the auto-rickshaw.

Her loan group members include: Allah Rakhi B. who wants to start a milk business; Anwar B. who wants to buy rickshaw; Bashiran B. who wants to start an ice business; and Rafia B. who wants to start a seasonal wheat business.This is loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible

loans.use: To buy for an auto-rickshaw

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Yasemeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasemeen B., wife of Mr. I., is a mother of four daughters. Yasmeen and her husband have a business where they embroider and stitch clothes. Their monthly income is $100. Yasmeen would like apply for a loan to buy one more sewing machine and train her girls.

Her loan group includes: Naseem B. and Bilquis B. want to start a seasonal wheat business; Zubaida B. wants to buy a goat; Hanifan B. wants to start milk business. This is a loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim B., a mother of five children, is the widow of A. G.. All her children have finished 10th grade in school. She would like to apply for a loan to buy a rickshaw for her elder son's business, as well as to help one of her sons who works in a furniture shop where he polishes and paints furniture.

Her loan group includes: Naseem B. who would like expand her paint shop; Zubaida B. who would like to buy goats; Shamim B. who would like to buy horse; and Sumera B. who would like to expand her goat business. This is group loan will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Dara Salam 2007-2 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Diana E.. Diana is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman.Their four children range in age from 4 to 18 years old and the children go to school. Each week, Diana earns approximately 75 Sudanese pounds ($US 37) in profits from selling bread and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand the business.

Diana is joined in her small group by Hanan J., Suzi S., Hawa J., and Florence A.. Hanan J. sells bread and wants to build a hotel. Suzi S. brews alcoholic beverages and wants a loan to open up a bar. Hawa J. wants to expand her bread-selling business. Florence A. currently sells at a hotel and is requesting a loan for the construction of houses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand a bread-selling business

loans.name: Dina 2010-3 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Grace B., who is a 45-year-old widow. She is currently in the business of selling at her shop and is requesting a loan to expand the shop. She has 4 children ranging from in age from 12 to 25 years and her children go to school. Grace operates a shop at which, each week, she makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds ($US 49.00) in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand the business.

Grace is joined in her group by Mary S., Veronica S., Cipora M., and Suzi S.. Mary S. sells oil and wants to increase her inventory. Veronica S. currently sells bread and wants a loan to open up a bakery. Cipora M. also sells bread and wants to buy a motor bike for transportation. Suzi S. brews alcoholic beverages and is requesting a loan for the construction of a house.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: expand the shop

loans.name: London 2014-4 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Busena K.. She is 28 years old and is married to a husband who is an accountant. Busena has 2 children, ages 1 and 5. Busena currently sells rice and beans at a hotel and each week makes approximately 35 Sudanese pounds ($US 17) in profits. With the additional profits from her loan, she hopes to construct a hotel.

Busena is joined in her small group by Kejia K., Mary K., Glady Y., and Erico I.. Kejia K. sells bread and will use her part of the loan to buy clothes for sale. Mary K. currently sells beer and wants a loan to open up a bar. Glady Y. brews local beer and wants to buy motor bike. Erico I. sells charcoal and will use the loan to increase her inventory.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: For the construction of a hotel

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en: Jamila, wife of Mr. Y., has been a resident of  the city of Kasur for the last 23 years. She is the mother of five children: one daughter and four sons. Her daughter is married; her eldest son received an education up until 7th grade and now drives a tractor; her younger son works in a factory; and her youngest son is enrolled in school. Jamila is a housewife, while her husband is a farmer, and she looks after the land in the absence of her husband. They have two buffalos that produce milk which is sold door to door by her employees. She would like to apply for a loan to buy anoter buffalo to expand her milk business.

loans.use: To expand the milk business

loans.name: Isreal 2028-5 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Poyube K.. She is 45 years old and is a widow. She has 5 children ranging from in age from 2 to 27 and her children go to school. Poyube currently sells clothes and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. Each week, Poyube makes approximately 55 Sudanese pounds ($US 27.00) in profits. She hopes to increase her earnings by using her loan to stock more clothes.

Poyube is joined in her small group by Diana N., Sara J., Joice J., and Diana A.. Diana N. runs a hotel and wants to expand the hotel. Sara J. makes tea and wants a loan to open up a restaurant. Joice J. brews local beer and wants to expand the business. Diana A. also sells local beer and is requesting a loan to stock more sorghum (from which the beer is made).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Khursheed

texts.en: Khursheed Baji is the wife of R. M. and has been living in a famous city called Kasur for the last 25 years. She is the mother of seven children: four daughters and three sons. All of her sons are enrolled in a local school. Khursheed Baji’s daughters are all married. She is a housewife and looks after her buffaloes. Her husband has the business in animal food. Her husband’s monthly income is $150. She also makes embroidered ribbons, used to tie-up hair and sells them in a big market. Her earnings are $50 in a month. She applies for a loan for her husband to buy animal food to sell in the market and earn a good profit.

loans.use: Improve the financial condition

loans.name: Sugran

texts.en: Sughran Baji is the wife of Faqeer H. who has been living in a city in Pakistan. Her husband is a shopkeeper by profession. She looks after the shop in his absence because her husband works as a security guard. Her daily income is $4 to $6. She applies for a loan for her husband’s business. Her husband wants to diversify the products so that the customers can buy everything from his shop. She plans to invest all her loan amount into her husband’s grocery shop to earn a good profit.

loans.use: Diversify the business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Rashidan

texts.en: Rashidan Baji is the wife of K. M. and has been living in a city called Riwind in Pakistan for the last 30 years. Rashidan Baji has a milk business. She has two buffaloes. Her husband sells the milk in a shop and earns a profit. Rashidan Baji and her husband are not educated, but they strive for their children and for their education. Her children are settled in their desired work now. She is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo and sell their milk in a market.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina M., 42, married mother of 3 children, sells charcoal and groundnuts in a nearby community market. She has been in this business for almost twelve years now. With this business, she has supported her first son to complete senior high school. She wants to use this loan to buy more supplies of charcoal and bags of groundnuts to increase her stock. She believes this will help to provide her with increased income for her children’s education.

Amina belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and bags of groundnuts for re-sale

loans.name: Sugran

texts.en: Sugran Baji is a wife of a milkman named Mr. H.. She is the mother of three children:  two sons and one daughter. Her sons are married. Her husband is the owner of 11 buffaloes. Her daily income is $20. Her husband has been in this profession since his childhood. Her son runs a motorbike shop, where he rents motorbikes. Sugran Baji helps her husband in selling milk. She goes to the market and sells the milk in a shop. She is applying for a loan for her husband. She wants to invest that amount in her husband's business and wants to hire some employees to help him in his work.

loans.use: Expand the milk business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica A., 39 and married with four children currently schooling, owns and operates a little grocery shop selling items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits, etc. at the local market. She wants to use this loan to buy rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted spices, washing soaps and powders, etc. to expand her business. She hopes to make good income from the expanded business to finance her children’s education to provide them with life opportunities better than what she had.

Monica belongs to the community group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted spices, washing soaps and powders, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Munawar

texts.en: Munawar Baji is a wife of S. H. who is a fruit seller. She is the mother of four sons. One of her sons helps her husband in fruit selling. From the income of the fruit business she was able to marry her three sons. Her husband has been in this profession since his childhood because his father and his forefathers were doing the same business for many, many years. She is applying for a loan for her husband’s fruit business.

loans.use: To expand the fruit business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary E. is a 35-year-old businesswoman. She is a wife and the mother of four children who are in school.

She is a very industrious woman and her biggest wish is to provide a quality education for her children to give them better opportunities in life. Mary owns and operates a grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk, etc.

She wants to use the loan to increase her stock of goods. With an increased variety of stock, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children.

She belongs to the community group called Faith Trust Group. Members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks and cooking oil.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena C. is 53 years old. She is married with three boys and two girls who are currently in school. She works very hard to support her husband in taking care of their children in school.

She operates a clothing shop in the community market. She sells various kinds of textile cloths with both traditional and industrial designs as well as linen materials. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of cloth and linen materials to increase her stock so she can earn more income for her business and family.

She is a member of the group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of men's and women's textiels and linen materials.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is 36 years old. She is married with three children who are currently in school. She also has been taking care of two young siblings at the school since they lost their parents.

She sells baby clothes, diapers, powder, napkins, detergents, feeding bottles as well as plastic chairs. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of baby clothes, napkins, diapers, baby oil, detergents and plastic materials to increase her stock to earn more income so she can provide her children with a good education.

She is a member of the group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans. .

loans.use: To buy more supplies of baby clothes, napkins, diapers, baby oil, detergents and plastic materials.

loans.name: Afua

texts.en:
Afua Tawiah is 58 years old. She has a husband and seven children. Through hard work and her support with her husband, they have managed to support all the seven children so they were able to finish school and start working.

She operates a clothing shop in the community market. She sells various kinds of textile cloth with both traditional and industrial designs as well as rice and vegetable oil. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of cloth and bags of rice and gallons of vegetable oil to increase her stock so she can earn more income for her business and family.

She is a member of the group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of men's and women's textiles, bags of rice and gallons of vegetable oil .

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Zuhran

texts.en: Zuhran Baji is a wife of Mr. F. who has been living in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She is a mother of five sons. Her husband is a milkman by profession. Zuhran Baji has 5 buffaloes in her home. Her husband gets milk from cows in the morning and she helps him in selling the milk. Zuhara’s husband charged 50 cents per kilogram of milk. She applies for a loan to buy one more buffalo to expand her husband’s milk business.

loans.use: To expand the milk business

loans.name: Freedom 2030-6 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Doruka M.. She is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 6 children, ranging in age from 3 to 28 and her children go to school. Doruka sells bread and each week, she makes approximately 75 Sudanese pounds ($US 37.00) in profits. With the additional profits from her loan, she hopes to open a bakery .

Doruka is joined in her small group by Cicilia S., Kwaje U., Lucia P. , and Charisty J.. Cicilia S. sells clothes and wants to expand her shop. Kwaje U. sells charcoal and plans to increase her stock. Lucia P. currently sells bread and wants to initiate cattle rearing. Charisty J. makes tea and is requesting a loan to open a restaurant.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Open a bakery

loans.name: Régina

texts.fr:
Born on October 17, 1979 in TOVICLIN (in COUFFO County) in the Southwest of Benin, Ms. Régina A. is married and the mother of a girl, Oluwatob, age 5. She is a seller of women's undergarments and shoes. A traveling saleswoman in the beginning, she was able to make a deal on a shop located about 500 meters from her home, where she is going to become situated in order to better serve her customer base. She is requesting a loan to procure supplies and to meet customer demands.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 17 octobre 1979 à TOVICLIN dans le département du COUFFO au Sud-ouest du BENIN, dame A. Régina est mariée et mère d’une fille OLUWATOBI âgée de 5 ans. Elle est revendeuse de sous vêtement féminin et de chaussures dames. Ambulante au départ, elle a pu négocier une boutique située à environ 500 mètres de son domicile où elle va s’installer afin de mieux servir sa clientèle. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour s’approvisionner et répondre aux attentes de ses clients.

loans.use: To buy one bale of undergarments and a half bag of shoes

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Christine P.. She is 30 years old and is a widow with 6 children ranging in age from 9 to 29. Her children go to school. Christine currently sells bread. Each week, she makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds ($US 49.00) in profits and, with the additional profits from her loan, she hopes to open a bakery .

Christine is joined in her small group by Ava Kiden, Victoria John, and Jenifa Mathayo. Ava Kiden sells tea and will use her portion of the loan to pay school fees. Victoria John sells at the hotel and wants the loan to open lodgings. Jenifa Mathayo sells local beer and wants to open a bar.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To open a bakery

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah K. is 46 years old. She is married with five children. Two have completed senior high school and the others are in junior high school.

Hannah owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, etc. She is also an interior decorator with skill in decorating rooms and businesses.

She wants to use the loan to buy more stocks of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc. to expand her business. She believes this will help her earn more income to buy additional tools for her decoration work.

She belongs to the community group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc.

loans.name: Abdumuslim

texts.ru:
Abdumuslim P. is a resident of the Nurek region. He is 24 years old, is married and has 1 child. Abdumuslim raises livestock. He purchases calves at the market, fattens them and resells them at the local market for profit. This business is the sole source of income for his family. Today, Abdumuslim would like to purchase another calf and he needs money to do this. He has decided to take out a 6 month loan.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Пиров Абдумуслим житель района Нурек. Возраст 24 года, женат, имеет 1 ребенка. Абдумуслим занимается животноводством. Он покупает на рынке молодых бычков , откармливает их и перепродает на местном рынке по выгодной ему цене. Эта деятельность является единственным источником дохода его семьи. В данный момент клиент хочет купить очередного бычка.Для чего ему нужны деньги.Поэтому он решил взять кредит сроком на 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase calf

loans.name: Fayzullo

texts.ru:
Fayzullo S. lives in the Nurek region. He is 46 years old, is married and has 3 children. Fayzullo has been raising livestock for over 15 years. He raises both small and large horned animals. Since it is very hard to find a permanent job in a rural area, this is the main source of income for many families. Fayzullo purchases young livestock at the market, fattens them and resells them for a profit. This business helps him to support his family. Today, the client would like to purchase another calf. This is why he needs money. He has decided to take out a loan for 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Сафарзод Файзулло житель района Нурек. Возраст 46 лет , женат , имеет 3 детей. Файзулло более 15 лет занимается животноводством. Он разводит мелкий и крупный рогатый скот. Так как в сельской местности очень трудно найти постоянную работу-эта деятельность является основным источником дохода многих семей. Файзулло покупает на рынке молодых сельхоз.животных ,откармливает и продает по более выгодной ему цене. Этот бизнес помогает ему содержать свою семью. В данный момент клиент хочет купить очередного бычка. Для чего ему нужны деньги . Поэтому он решил взять кредит сроком на 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase calf

loans.name: Zaituni Namusoke's Group

texts.en:
Zaituni is leader of a group with four members. She is 48 years old and married with eight children. They are between 30 and 12 years old. Two of them are in school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban.

She buys charcoal from vendors to sell at wholesale and retail. She also makes pancakes and chapattis and fries cassava. Because she carries out her business near a school, her clients are the villagers and school children.

Her main challenges are the unstable prices and limited capital. She wants to increase her stock and to contribute to her family's welfare. Her biggest dream is to build a commercial block of rental houses to earn her more income.

Zaituni has successfully paid back more than three loans.

loans.use: To stock more charcoal and ingredients for frying snacks.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Gulru.

texts.ru:
Gurlu Rahmatove lives in Nurek with her parents. She is 33 years old, not married. She has a secondary education. She is a teacher in the middle school in Nurek. The family doesn't own their own cow, but it is very expensive to purchase sour milk products at the market. This is why Gulru decided to take out a loan and buy a dairy cow. She plans to repay the loan in three months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Ezhevskaya, Kiva translator

Рахматова Гулру жительница района Нурек. Возраст 33 года, не замужем. Образование средние . Гулру работает учительницей в средней школе района Нурек. Живет с родителями . Своей коровы в их семье нет. А покупать на рынке кисло-молочную продукцию очень дорого. Поэтому Гулру решила взять кредит и купить дойную корову.Планирует погасить кредит в течение 3 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow.

loans.name: Teo Kato’S Group

texts.en:
Teo K. is a 40-year-old widow with six children. The oldest is 27; three are still in school. She works in Wakaliga, a semi-urban area just outside Kampala where she sells waragi, or local brew. She buys it wholesale in 20-liter jerry cans in a nearby village for 30,000 Ugandan shillings (about $17 US) and retails it for 50,000 shillings (close to $30).

She has been doing this business for the past two years. With a new loan, she will be able to buy more and invest her capital. The extra money will help her look after her children at home, especially with the school fees for their education. Her future goal is to buy a plot in Bulenga, a Kampala suburb (within the city limits) and build a house.

Teo has successfully paid back more than five loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Damascus 2025-8 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Rose W.. She is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a builder. Rose has 4 children ranging from age 2 to 20, and her children go to school. Rose sells bread, and each week she makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds ($US 49.00) in profits. With the additional profits from her loan, she hopes to open a bakery .

Rose is joined in her small group by Betty K., Roda J., Rose W., and Jenty A.. Betty K. sells bread and wants to use the loan to construct a house. Roda J. and Rose W. sell local beer and each wants the loan to open a bar. Jenty A. runs a hotel and is requesting a loan to open lodgings.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: open up bakery

loans.name: Margaret Kasweera’S Group

texts.en:
Margaret is 24 years old and lives in Nalukolongo, a neighborhood near the outskirts of Kampala. She is married with two children, both in school. For the past three years, she has been making candles using a machine her husband bought that enables her to make 12 large candles at a time. She trained with Indians who taught her how to use the machine and, with her first loan from MCDT, started her candle-making business. She sells to shops at wholesale and at retail along the roadside. A box of wax ranges in cost from 45,000 to 50,000/= (Ugandan shillings, between $27-$29 US). She makes a profit of about 50,000/= per box of wax.

With this new loan, she would like to buy a second machine that makes 50 candles at a time in a smaller size. The profit from her business will make it possible for her children to continue their studies and for her family to construct a house.

She has successfully paid back more than five loans.

loans.use: To purchase new candle-making machine to produce more candles of smaller sizes

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita Y. is a 45-year-old widow and mother of six children. She lost her husband in a car accident six years ago and has since then been a single parent.

She is really industrious, and she works with the motivation of supporting her children’s education to provide them with better life opportunities in the future. At the moment, two of her children are in school, two have completed school and the last two have not yet started school because of the high financial burden.

She is a food vendor and sells cooked plantains and yams with stew. She also sells groundnuts, beans and yams in the community market.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bunches of plantains, beans, yams and groundnuts to increase her stock of goods. She believes the loan will increase her working capital and offer her the opportunity to increase production so she can earn a good income for her children’s education.

She belongs to the community group called Decency Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of plantains, beans, yams and groundnuts.

loans.name: Pamela Nabuuma’S Group

texts.en:
Pamela N. lives in the Rubaga Division of Kampala. She is 32 years old, married, and has three children, ages 6, 4, and 2. For the past four years she has been selling charcoal, thanks to an initial loan from MCDT. She buys sacks of charcoal from villagers for 18,000/= (Ugandan shillings, about $10 US) and sells it in much smaller amounts, starting at 500/= (about 30 cents). Ultimately, she makes a profit of about 7,000/= per sack (about $4).

She rents a stand in Kibuye where she sells her charcoal. Sometimes it is difficult because people ask for charcoal on credit and don’t pay her back, or people try to con her or steal her things.

With a new loan, she would like to start another retail business selling items used daily in the home, such as salt, sugar, rice, and cooking oil. With this expanded inventory, she will be able to earn a regular income. Her ultimate goal is to construct a house in the Wakiso district.

Pamela has successfully paid back more than five loans.

loans.use: To open a shop selling essential commodities

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick B. is a 58-year-old trader. He is married with nine children. He is quite old with very limited strength, yet he cannot shed his responsibility of caring for his children while they are in school.

It is his daily dream to provide a quality education for his children to give them better lives in the future.

Patrick owns and operates a grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, evaporated milk, etc. He wants to use the loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks and cooking oil to increase his stock of goods.

With an increased variety of stock, he hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of his children.

He belongs to the community group called Decency Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mukerabirori

texts.en: MUKABIRORE she is widow with 4 orphaned children that she has adopted. She is surviving by selling milk and traditional cake. With the loan requested, she will expand her business.

loans.use: To increase her business

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard N. is 33 years old. He is married with two kids. Richard has been a taxi driver for the past 10 years.

Taxi driving has been his major occupation and the main source of income for his family. He takes passengers from the local lorry station to nearby towns at a transport fare of 30 pesewas (0.3 cedis -- Ghanaian currency) per head.

However, his business is in a crisis of late because his car has broken down and he needs money for repairs. He therefore requests a loan to enable him to maintain his taxi car so he can resume his business and earn income to support his family and get his kids back to school.

He belongs to the community group called Decency Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To maintain his taxi car to resume his business.

loans.name: Ikrom

texts.en:
Ikrom A. is 36 years old. He and his wife have three children. Ikrom is a farmer. He has been working the land since he was 25. Ikrom grows wheat, rice, and other crops and he also raises cattle. During the season, Ikrom works in the field from early morning until late at night. Five years ago Ikrom started by farming wheat and rice on a plot of 0.10 hectares. Currently he devotes 0.50 hectares to the cultivation of onions. As his business stabilizes and grows Ikrom hopes that it will cover the mounting expenses he will face as his dearest children grow up.

Ikrom is asking for a loan of 990 $ US dollars over a term of 7 months. Ikrom would use the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer, and also to buy livestock and pay the salaries of seasonal workers. Ikrom thanks everyone for their support and promises to repay the loan fully and on time.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, and livestock

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr:
Born around 1954 in PORTO NOVO (in OUEME County) in the southeast of BENIN, Ms. Elisabeth T. currently lives in COTONOU, where she sells corn wholesale and retail and also various kinds of fruit, especially oranges. The mother of two children, Mireille and Prudence, she is often aided by Mireille, who goes from district to district to sell corn by the kilogram. She is requesting this loan to give her business a new direction.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née vers les années 1954 à PORTO NOVO dans le département de l’OUEME au sud-est du BENIN, dame T. Elisabeth vit actuellement à COTONOU où elle vend du maïs en gros et en détail et divers fruits surtout des oranges. Mère de 2 enfants Mireille et Prudence, elle est souvent aidée par Mireille qui passe de quartier en quartier pour vendre au kilogramme le maïs. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour donner de nouvelles orientations à ses activités.

loans.use: To buy 6 bags of corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of beauty products for a small beauty parlor

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr:
Born in 1972 in SAKETE (in PLATEAU County) in the Southeast of BENIN, Ms. Madeleine O. is married and the mother of four. She sells sardines, canned tomatoes, and vegetable oil (from palm kernels or peanuts), cookies, and various other food items. She discovered a commercial zone in her village where she goes every weekend to display her different goods. She would also like to establish a sales outlet in Cotonou, her place of residence. And so she is applying for this loan to realize her noble ambition.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née en 1972 à SAKETE dans le département du PLATEAU au Sud-est du BENIN, dame O. Madeleine est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vend des sardines, des tomates en boîtes, de l’huile végétale (de palmiste ou d’arachide), des biscuits et autres divers produits vivriers. Elle a découvert une zone commerciale dans son village où elle va tous les weekends pour exposer ses différents produits. Elle voudrait également installer un point de vente à Cotonou son lieu de résidence. Elle sollicite donc ce prêt pour réaliser sa noble ambition.

loans.use: To buy 30 boxes of sardines and 25 boxes of canned tomatoes

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel O. is 43 years old. He is married with seven children. He is a supplier and retailer of local meat like beef, goat meat, mutton and pork to food vendors and local restaurant operators.

He buys his supplies from villages and sells to his customers. With his small working capital, he is not able to buy larger quantities to make enough income.

He wants to use the loan to buy bulk beef, goat meat, mutton and pork to serve his customers good quality meat for their meals. He believes this will provide him with increased income to expand his business and also finance his children’s education.

He belongs to the community group called Decency Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy bulk beef, goat meat, mutton and pork.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in beauty products to grow her small business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new collection of shoes and beauty products for her business

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.ru:
Rafoat T. is a 45-year-old woman with two children, a son and a daughter, both of whom are married. For twenty years Rafoat has worked as a doctor in a pediatric health clinic. As government-paid employees, clinic staff receive an extremely meager salary, so Rafoat would like to take out a loan in order to make repairs to her apartment. Rafoat wishes to receive credit from KIVA and spend it for buying paint , wallpaper and other belongings.Because her son works as a driver and her husband has left to work in Russia, she is sure that she will be able to pay back the loan on time from money which they send her .She needs in extra loan as she want to start her repairs as soon as posible; as the limit of electricity will start in autumn and repairs can be stop about it.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Тураходжаева Рафоат, женщина возраст 45 лет мать двоих детей, дочь и сын.Обоих детей она уже выдала замуж и женила сына.Сама работает врачем в детской поликлинике уже 20 лет.По причине, что бюджетным работникам зарплата составляет у нас очень мизерный размер, а она хочет провести ремонт квартиры.Рафоат планирует получить займ с КИВЫ и потратить деньги на покупку красок,oбоев и других принадлежностей для ремонта,а так же на оплату работы мастерам..Ее сын работает водителем , муж в данный момент отутствует, т.к. уехал в Россию на заработки. Они присылают деньги ежемесячно и она планирует вносить ежемесячные погашения с этих денег.Она очень нуждаеться в срочном займе, так как летом планирует полностью закончить ремонт.(проблемы лимта электоэнергии,которые начинаються осенью,могут задержать ремонт) .

loans.use: Apartment Repairs

loans.name: Christiane

texts.fr:
Born around 1975 in SAKETE (in PLATEAU County) in the south of BENIN, Ms. Christiane B. currently lives in Cotonou, where she is married and the mother of three. Her eldest, Rose, is in 4th grade, and the second child Jacques, is in 3rd grade, both at the private school Saint Paul of Avotrou. The third child is five years old but doesn't attend school. Having a great deal of experience in the distribution of beauty products, Ms. B. buys beauty products and toothpaste at the DANTOKPA market and in LOME, a city in the neighboring country of Togo. Currently, she is experiencing some difficulties filling all her orders, so she is requesting this loan to cope with the new orders.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née vers les années 1975 à SAKETE dans le département du PLATEAU au sud du BENIN, dame B. Christiane vit actuellement à COTONOU où elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Son ainée Rose est en classe de CM1 et le deuxième enfant Jacques en classe de CE2 tous à l’école privée Saint Paul d’AVOTROU. Le troisième enfant a 5 ans mais ne fréquente pas. D’une grande expérience dans la distribution des produits de beauté, dame B. Christiane achète les produits de beauté et des pâtes dentifrices au marché DANTOKPA et à LOME, une ville de l’état voisin du TOGO. Actuellement, elle éprouve quelques difficultés pour satisfaire toutes les demandes d’où elle sollicite ce crédit pour faire face aux nouvelles demandes.

loans.use: To buy 30 hair extensions, a box of toothpaste, and various beauty products

loans.name: Bilson

texts.en:
Bilson D. is 47 years old. He is married with four children. He has been an auto electrician for the past 15 years.

He learned his knowledge and skills in an apprenticeship, and he is now a master of auto electricity. He services all kinds cars and vehicles with electrical and battery problems. At the moment, he is training three young men and imparting his knowledge and skills to them to give them future job opportunities.

Bilson wants the loan to buy more tools and raw materials like scrap batteries, wires and car parts. He wants to provide his clients with better services for increased income to expand his workshop and for his family.

He belongs to the community group called Grace to Grace Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more tools and raw materials like scrap batteries, wires and car parts.

loans.name: Sattorova

texts.ru:
Sattorova M. is 54 years old and has four children, already with their own families. She lives with her husband. During the day she sells goods at the market, but besides her business, she also works the night shift at the hospital as a nurse. Once she found out from friends about loans, she decided to increase her business's sales. She approached Microinvest in order to expand her selection of summer wear.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Сатторова Матлюба, возраст 54 года, замужем имеет 4 детей , все дети уже семейные,она сейчас живет с мужем вдвоем, работает помимо бизнеса в ночьную смену в больнице медсестрой , а днем выходит на рынок торговать. Узнав от подруг о кредите она решила расширить свой товарооборот, хочет добавить в свой ассортимент летних товаров.Для этого она пришла к нам в Микроинвест.

loans.use: Underclothes sales

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.ru:
Sharofat is 57, married, and has three sons. Two sons are currently working in Russia, and their wives live with Sharofat. To keep her youngest son from being drafted into the army, she sent him and her husband to live in Kyrgystan.

Sharofat and her daughters-in-law have not had it easy. They have cows and used to sell milk and milk products, but now each daughter-in-law has small children who also need the milk. Raising and selling livestock is the only business in the town. Sharofat gradually sold the sheep she had, but it’s clear that selling them now means that later there will be nothing to live on. Her sons are little by little sending small amounts of money, always setting aside a certain amount to send to her son and husband in Kyrgystan to keep her son out of the army. Neighbors encouraged her to contact Microinvest and develop a livestock business. She and her daughters-in-law plan to use the remaining money to buy wool for knitting rugs to sell (they have prior experience with this). She plans to acquire more livestock, so that after 3 months she can sell at a higher price.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Шарофат 57 лет, она замужем имеет 3 сыновей. Сейчас двое сына находятся в России на заработке их жены живут с Шарофат. А младшего сына она с мужем отправила в Киргизистан, так как его могут забрать в армию.

Шарофат и ее невестам приходилось не легко, у них ест коровы , раньше они продавали молоко и молочные изделия, сейчас когда у каждой невестки есть маленькие дети, они тоже нуждаются в молоке. А откорм и продажа скота является единственным бизнесом в селе. Шарофат по немного продавала имеющиеся овец, но теперь она поняла, что если продаст, то дальше будет не на что жить. Сыновья по мало присылают не большую сумму, откладывая необходимую сумму денег отправляла в Киргизию сыну и мужу, что бы удержать сына от армии. Соседи посоветовали обратиться в Микроинвест, что бы развить бизнес скота, а на оставшийся деньги она и ее невесты планируют покупать шерсть, вязать ковры и продавать (они этим раньше занимались). Она планирует приобрести еще скот, что бы через 3 месяца продать подороже.

loans.use: Feeding and Selling Livestock

loans.name: Anorgul

texts.en:
Anorgul B. is 48 years old. She is married, and the couple has three children, only one of whom is still under their care. Anorgul has worked in agriculture for fifteen years, and in that time has gained much experience and a love for the land. She grows rice, wheat, peas and other crops. Each year Anorgul grows enough to feed the family and sells the surplus.

Anorgul’s husband, who appears in the photo, helps her sell the yield. The farm generates a steady income and with it Anorgul is able to support her family. Anorgul is asking for a loan of 1000$ US Dollars to be repaid over a term of 7 months. Anorgul would use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. Anorgul thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan fully and on time.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Zarifa

texts.en:
Zarifa Mahmudova Zarifa is 22 years old. She and her husband are raising two children. Zarifa’s children are small now, but she is already working hard to ensure the best future for them.

Zarifa is a farmer. She and her husband have 2.0 hectares of land where she grows wheat, rice, carrots, and other crops. She also raises cattle. As a rule Zarifa and her husband grow enough to feed the family and sell the surplus.

With the loan she hopes to receive from IMON Zarifa hopes to produce a bumper crop that she can sell in the market at prices attractive to buyers. She is asking for a loan of 990$ US dollars over a term of 7 months. Zarifa would use most of the loan to buy fertilizer and other supplies to amend the soil and some of the loan to buy calves. Zarifa thanks everyone for their support and promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and livestock

loans.name: Inom

texts.en:
Inom A. is 37 years old. He is married and has two children. He loves his children very much and does the best he can to make them happy and give them a good education.

Inom runs a farm where he grows wheat and rice. Inom is an experienced farmer; he has worked the land for the last 10 years. The business is stable and generates the main income for the family.

However, this business requires lots of work and supplies. Inom needs to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and fuel. He also needs to pay the salaries of seasonal workers. Inom is asking for a loan of 1000 $ US dollars over a term of 7 months. Inom thanks everyone for supporting him. This is his first loan, and he promises to repay the loan fully and on time.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and  fuel, and to pay the salaries of hired seasonal workers

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya B. is 40 years old. Her husband's name is B. A.. She resides in an area of Kasur named Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is a mother of four children. She is a housewife. She does household work. She is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Manzooran B. wants a loan to buy a sewing machine. Farzana B. wants a loan to start a grocery shop. Hamidan B. wants a loan to buy a donkey cart.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Facilitate businesses

loans.name: Ndiaya

texts.fr:
Mrs. S., born in 1961, married, and raising 4 children, has requested a loan to purchase cloth, shoes, etc. to expand her inventory. She is planning to sell her wares from door-to-door. This is her first loan which she will reimburse in one single payment in 6 months, when the loan term is up.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mme S. née en 1961, mariée avec 04 enfants en charge souhaite acquérir un crédit pour acheter des tissus, des chaussures et divers pour augmenter son stock de marchandise. elle va faire un commerce ambulant pour écouler la marchandise. voici son premier prét qu'elle va rembourser en une seule échéance au bout de six mois.

loans.use:
Purchase and re-sale of clothes, shoes

Achat et revente de vétements, chaussures

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia B. is a 50 year old lady. Her husband's name is D. M.. She is a mother of one son. D. M. is the breadwinner of her family. Due to lots of responsibilities he couldn’t give his son a better education. Asia B. wants to apply for a loan for her husband, who wants to run his grocery shop.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members named Sakian, Rashidan, Naziran and Hajra who also want a loan to buy a buffalo.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Facilitate businesses

loans.name: Seema's Group

texts.en:
Seema B. is 44 years old. Her husband's name is D. H. who is also 44 years old. She is a mother of seven children. None of them have a education because of the bad circumstances. She wants to buy a donkey cart; that’s why she need a loan.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Fajri B. wants a loan for her grocery shop. Khursheed B. wants a loan to buy buffalo. Sughran B. wants a loan for her shoe business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To improve their financial situation

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina B. is a 55 year old lady. Her husband's name is D. A., who is 10 years older than her. Sakina is a housewife. Her husband runs a small canteen-like hotel. Therefore Sakina B. applies for a loan for her husband so that he would be able to increase his profit from his canteen.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Azmin B. who wants a loan to buy buffalo. Razia B. wants a loan to buy goats. Amina B. wants a loan to buy a piece of land. Razia B. wants a loan for her milk business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Anwar's Group

texts.en:
Anwari B. is 28 years old. Her husband's name is M. I., who is two years older than her. She is a mother of two children: one daughter and one son. Her husband has a furniture business. She wants to expand her husband’s business, therefore she has applied for a loan.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members named: Rubina B. who wants a loan to buy a sewing machine. Yasmeen B. wants a loan to buy a shop where her husband can start work as a barber. Sughran B. wants a loan to buy tea sets for her cafeteria.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Expand their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen B. is 47 years old and the leader of this group mentioned below. Her husband's name is K. H., who is 54 years old. K. H. is a driver by profession. She is a mother of one son. She is applying for a loan to buy a rickshaw for her husband.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members named: Bashiran B., who wants to expand her grocery shop. Nasreen B., wants loan to buy a fruit cart. Kosar B. wants a loan to diversify the products of her grocery shop. Farzana B. wants a loan to make curtains of wood and cloth.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en: Shahnaz is 35 years old, just five years younger than her husband.  His name is L. A. and he is an expert in making flower pots. Shahnaz wants a loan of $725 for her husband’s business so that he can expand his business and buy more materials.  She has been joined in her loan group by a few more members: Majidan wants a loan to repair her van; Rubina wants a loan to expand her flower pot business; Munawar wants a loan to buy a donkey cart.  This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en: Kosar is 30 years old, just eight years younger than her husband whose name is Mr. H.. Her husband is a driver by profession. He can easily drive any vehicle. They are planning on buying a new rickshaw, and therefore Kosar has applied for a loan of $725.  She has been joined in her loan group a few more members: Fozia wants loans to buy sanitary items for resale; Geo wants a loan to buy a horse cart; and Karshid wants a loan to expand her milk business.  This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Marcelina's Group

texts.en:
The Committee of Entrepreneuring Women is a program carried out by Fundación Paraguaya which targets groups of enterprising women who create a village bank through which they receive assistance in terms of loans. The main goal is to give them the opportunity to carry out economic activities which enable them to live in dignity and contribute to a better quality of life in their homes. Lending to poor women creates a cascading effect that brings social and economic benefits to a whole family, and thus to the entire community. What is more, the sense of belonging to a group gives these poor women the energy and motivation to reach success.

In a remote area of Carapegua called Quiindy, a group of women heard about The Committee of Entrepreneuring Women. They set up a meeting and shared their desire of changing their world for the better by working very hard. These hopeful words stimulated optimism among these women and they decided to form a Committee.

Among the businesses these women run are grocery stores and sales of chipas and crafts. Some of these women are weavers. They need the credit to buy the materials related to their businesses; for instance, threads, fabrics, crafts, and ingredients to prepare chipas and others.

loans.use: Purchase of threads, fabrics, crafts, ingredients to prepare chipas and others.

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en: Shahnaz is 36 years and is married to M.S., who is a milkman by profession. He has done this for the last six years. Currently, Shahnaz and her husband live in a two room brick house in Kasur, Pakistan, which is famous for its sweetmeat.  She has applied for a loan of $625 to help with her husband’s business.  Shahnaz has been joined in her loan group by two more members:  Sabiha wants a loan to buy a buffalo; and Sugran wants a loan to expand her shuttering business.  This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Aida's Group

texts.en:
The Committee of Entrepreneuring Women is a program carried out by Fundación Paraguaya which targets groups of enterprising women who create a village bank through which they receive assistance in terms of loans. The main goal is to give them the opportunity to carry out economic activities which enable them to live in dignity and contribute to a better quality of life in their homes. Lending to poor women creates a cascading effect that brings social and economic benefits to a whole family, and thus to the entire community. What is more, the sense of belonging to a group gives these poor women the energy and motivation to reach success.

In a remote neighborhood located in Carepegua, a group of 20 women heard about the the Committee of Entrepreneuring Women and its profitable results. They decided to set up a meeting to know more about the program and without hesitation they formed a committee. They wanted to lift themselves out of poverty and to bring benefits to their own families.

Some of these women are door-to-door sales people. Some are craftswomen, others are teachers and the rest are weavers. They need the money to invest in the purchase of threads, fabrics, and sheets, among other things.

loans.use: To purchase threads, fabrics, and sheets, among other things.

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en: Jamila is 51 years and just three years younger than her husband, A. A.. Her husband is a fruit seller by profession. She resides in Kasur, Pakistan, in a two room brick house. She is requesting a loan of $675 to help expand her husband’s fruit business.  Jamila has been joined in her loan group by two more members: Nagina wants a loan to expand her curtain business; Nazia wants a loan to expand her scrap business.  This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Alicio

texts.en:
Alicio (29) is a single man who lives with his mother in Carapegua. Alicio is studying farming administration at the university. Next year he will be done with college and he will make his dream come true. He always wanted to have a degree. 

Hamacas (hammocks) are a type of swing very typical in Paraguay. Usually people take a siesta (nap) on the hamacas (swing). Since it is a tradition, there is always a huge demand for hamacas (swings).

From an early age Alicio started working with his mother in the production of swings and bedspreads. They started selling their products to different craft stores, but then they realized that they could sell on their own, and that would be much more profitable. Alicio is responsible for distributing the swings and bedspreads. Thanks to the increase in income, Alicio bought a car to make the distribution faster and more efficient. 

Alicio needs the credit in order to buy more raw materials such as threads, fabrics and others.

loans.use: Purchase threads, fabrics and others

loans.name: Gustavo

texts.en:
Gustavo C. Rojas (29) lives with his wife Petrona (31) and his three school-aged children in Cerrito, Carepegua.

Gustavo is a door-to-door sales person. While his wife makes bedspreads and swings, he goes house by house to different cities offering different types of products, most of them typical Paraguayan crafts including the bedspreads and swings his wife makes. Gustavo started with this activity ten years ago.

Today, Gustavo has his own house, motorcycle and a wide range of clients. He needs the credit to buy materials to sell.

loans.use: Purchase materials to sell, such as bedspreads, swings, and sheets.

loans.name: Isidro

texts.en:
Isidro C. (59) is married to Maria (59). The couple lives with their two sons in Ndavaru, Carapegua. Isidro is a door-to-door salesperson who offers different Paraguayan typical crafts. He started with this activity twenty years ago. 
Paraguayan woman produce fantastic fabrics called Nanduti and Ao po’i. These fabrics are 100 percent handmade. It is hard work and can take weeks or even months to finish a piece of this fabric. Isidro’s wife make Ao po’i and then he sells it.

In addition, the couple has their own farm where they cultivate cotton. So the entrepreneurial couple has three different source of income. The money provided by the credit will be used for the purchase of threads, sheets, t-shirts and others.

loans.use: Purchase threads, sheets, t-shirts and others.

loans.name: Sylviane

texts.fr:
Born on March 22, 1966 in BONOU (in PLATEAU County) located in the Southeast of BENIN, Ms. Sylviane H. is married to Julien AGOSSOU, a cabinetmaker by profession. Florent, Solange, and Mahugnon, her three children, are respectively in 11th grade, 9th grade, and 6th grade. As a merchant, she sells second-hand clothing in the first half of the day and ready-to-eat meals in the second half, by the main path linking the city to her neighborhood. She is requesting this loan to increase her sales figures for all her sales. Her retail site is often visited by a significant number of customers.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 22 mars 1966 à BONOU dans le département du PLATEAU situé au Sud-est du BENIN, dame H. Sylviane est mariée à AGOSSOU Julien, menuisier de profession. Florent, Solange et Mahugnon ses 3 enfants sont respectivement en classe de Première, Troisième et Sixième. Commerçante, elle vend pendant la première moitié de la journée de la friperie et pendant la seconde moitié du repas prêt à manger au bord de la voie principale reliant la ville à son quartier. Dame H. Sylviane sollicite ce crédit pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire sur l’ensemble de ses ventes. Son lieu de vente est souvent visité par un nombre non négligeable de clients.

loans.use: To buy 30 liters of peanut oil, 1 bale of second-hand clothing, and 50 liters of red palm oil

loans.name: María Pabla

texts.en:
Maria Pabla Gonzales is a single mother of four school-age children. They all live in San Roque Gonzales de Santa Cruz in Carepegua. She needs to work very hard since she has to raise four children on her own.

In the morning Maria Pabla goes door to door selling vegetables. In the afternoon, she and her children prepare natural medicines to sell in a well-known market in Carapegua.

Maria Pabla makes a lot of efforts to bring benefits to her extensive family. She admits it is not easy because she is alone and has many children. She tries harder and harder every day to lift her family out of poverty. She needs the money to buy vegetables.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables

loans.name: Miguel

texts.en:
Miguel Raul S. (24) is married to Estela (22), and the couple lives in Espartillar in Carapegua with their two school-aged sons.

Miguel is a door-to-door sales person. While his wife makes bedspreads, he goes house by house to different cities offering different types of products, most of them typical Paraguayan crafts including the bedspreads his wife makes. Miguel started with this activity many years ago, since his family used to do the same thing.

Today Miguel has a wide range of customers who are delighted with the wonderful crafts Miguel sells. Thanks to this profitable business, Miguel now has his own house with all the necessities to have a good quality of life. The loan will be used to purchase swings, bedspreads, sheets and shoes.

loans.use: Purchase of bedspreads, swings, sheets and shoes.

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr:
Born on June 10, 1976 in ADJOHOUN (in OUEME County), Ms. Elisabeth A. is married to Mr. Thomas DJOSSOU, a painter by profession. The mother of three children, she used to help her mom, who lived in the same neighborhood, to smoke and sell fish. Since the death of her mother in 2001, she has taken over this business. After smoking the fish, she delivers them to traveling saleswomen. To do this, she has hired two of her neighbors: Françoise, age 25, and Bernadette, age 30, who receive a daily wage. Due to the strong demand that she now has, she is experiencing some difficulties extending her business. This loan will go towards realizing her dream.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 10 juin 1976 à ADJOHOUN dans le département de l’OUEME, dame A. Elisabeth est mariée à monsieur DJOSSOU Thomas, peintre de profession. Mère de 3 enfants, elle aidait sa maman qui habitait le même quartier qu’elle à fumer et à vendre des poissons. Depuis le décès de sa mère en 2001, dame A. Elisabeth a pris le relais de cette activité. Après fumage des poissons, elle les livre aux vendeuses ambulantes. Elle a engagé pour cette activité deux de ses voisines de quartiers Françoise âgée de 25 ans et Bernadette âgée de trente 30 ans qui reçoivent une rémunération journalière. A cause de la forte demande qu’elle reçoit actuellement, elle éprouve des difficultés pour l’extension de son activité. Ce crédit participera à la réalisation de son rêve.

loans.use: To buy four big  stoves, two 50-liter drums of peanuts, and twenty baskets of fish

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr:
Jeanne H. was born around 1967 in Porto Novo. A widow responsible for three children (two girls and one boy), she lives in Ekpe in the commune of Seme Podji in the south-east of Benin. Since she lives not far from the Ekpe market which is especially lively at night, Mrs. H. sells prepared food: vegetable sauces, peanut sauces, cornmeal mush, etc. Since her foods are much appreciated, she would like to try out other types of dishes with her very faithful clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

H. Jeanne est née vers les années 1967 à PORTO NOVO. Veuve ayant à sa charge 3 enfants (2 filles et 1 garçon), elle réside à EKPE dans la commune de SEME PODJI au sud-est du BENIN. Ayant son domicile non loin du marché d’EKPE qui s’anime beaucoup plus la nuit, dame H. Jeanne vend du repas prêt à manger: sauce de légume, sauce d’arachide, pâte de maïs, etc. Son repas étant bien apprécier, elle envisage s’essayer à d’autres types de sauces et de pâtes qu’elle soumettra à sa clientèle qui lui est très fidèle.

loans.use:
Purchase of one basket of fresh fish, three baskets of condiments, ½ bag of corn and ½ bag of manioc flour

Achat de 1 panier de poisson frais, 3 paniers de condiments, ½ sac de maïs et ½ sac de farine de manioc.

loans.name: Yvette

texts.fr:
Born November 26, 1979 in Cotonou, Mrs. Yvette F. is married and mother of four children for whom she is still responsible. Selling rice and beans in a private primary school in her neighborhood, she brings in an average of 15,000 francs (about US$ 36) a day. She would like to sell more rice and beans, sauces and pastas. Since the enrollment of the school has grown and a great many students spend their afternoons at school where there is still no cafeteria, she would like to expand her business. She is therefore requesting this loan so that she can better serve her customers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née le 26 novembre 1979 à COTONOU, dame F. Yvette est mariée et mère de 4 enfants tous encore à sa charge. Vendeuse de riz et du haricot dans une école primaire privée de son quartier, elle réalise un chiffre d’affaire total de 15 000 francs en moyenne par jour. Elle souhaite vendre en plus du riz et du haricot, de la sauce et de la pâte. En raison de l’augmentation de l’effectif de cette école et du nombre impressionnant d’élèves qui passe leur après midi dans l’école qui ne dispose pas encore d’une de restauration, elle voudrait élargir son activité. Elle sollicite donc ce crédit pour mieux servir ses clients.

loans.use:
Purchase of 50 liters of peanut oil, 1 bag of rice, 2 bags of corn, various condiments, and 1 bag of dried beans

Achat de 50 litres d’huile d’arachide, 1 sac de riz, 2 sacs de maïs, divers condiments et 1 sac de haricot.

loans.name: Sissode

texts.fr:
Born in August 1958 in Ketou, Benin, Mrs. Sissode A. is a housewife and widow raising three children, aged 14, 12, and 10. She lives in the neighborhood called PK10 in the commune of Seme Podji. She cooks and sells cornmeal mush. To increase her earnings, she also sells corn which some women prefer to buy on credit, in view of their meager financial means. Since it is presently the season where the price of corn begins to rise, Mrs. A. is asking for this loan so that she can stock up on corn and avoid the rise in prices.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née en Août 1958 à KETOU au BENIN, dame A. Sissode est ménagère et veuve ayant sous sa charge 3 enfants âgés respectivement de 14, 12, et 10 ans. Elle habite le quartier PK10, un quartier de la commune de SEME PODJI. Elle prépare de la pâte de maïs bouillie qu’elle vend. Pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire, elle vend également le maïs dont d’autres femmes préfèrent l’achat à crédit, compte tenu de leur faible capacité financière. En raison de la saison actuelle où le prix du maïs commence par augmenter, dame A. Sissode sollicite ce crédit afin de vite s’approvisionner pour contourner la hausse du prix du maïs.

loans.use:
purchase of 9 bags of 50 kilograms of corn

Achat de 9 sacs de 50 kilogrammes de maïs.

loans.name: Rosa's Group

texts.en:
The Committee of Entrepreneuring Women is a program carried out by Fundación Paraguaya which targets groups of enterprising women who create a village bank through which they receive assistance in terms of loans. The main goal is to give them the opportunity to carry out economic activities which enable them to live in dignity and contribute to a better quality of life in their homes. Lending to poor women creates a cascading effect that brings social and economic benefits to a whole family, and thus to the entire community. What is more, the sense of belonging to a group gives these poor women the energy and motivation to reach success.

In a remote neighborhood located in Carepegua, a group of 15 women heard about the the Committee of Entrepreneuring Women and its profitable results. They decided to set up a meeting to know more about the program and, without hesitation, they formed a committee. They wanted to lift themselves out of poverty and to bring benefits to their own families.

Some of these women are craftswomen, others are salespeople, and the rest are weavers. They need the money to invest in the purchase of threads, fabrics, and sheets, among others.

loans.use: Purchase threads, fabrics, and sheets, among others.

loans.name: María Graciela

texts.en:
Maria Graciela V. (41) lives with her boyfriend, Omar Brigido Aquino Aguiar, in the city of San Ignacio in the neighborhood Maria Auxiliadora. The couple has two sons; one of them is married and lives with his own family.

Omar owns a repair shop for motorcycles; it is called “TALLER OMAR”. It is located in a strategic place, in one of the main streets where many people can see the shop and thus become Omar’s clients.

The money provided by this Kiva loan will be used to purchase motorcycle accessories and spare parts.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle accessories and spare parts.

loans.name: Ndaata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Ndaata G. is a member of the village bank of Mbousnakh in Thiès. She wants to increase her capital for her business selling cereals: millet, groundnuts, niébé (a type of peas), etc. The income from her business allows her to improve living conditions for her family and pay school fees for her children. Ndaata is requesting her 11th loan which will be reimbursed in one single repayment at the end of the loan term.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Ndaata G., mariée est membre du banc villageois de Mbousnakh à Thiès. Elle veut renforcer son capital pour le commerce de denrées alimentaires (mil, arachide, niébé, et autres). Les revenus tirés de son activité lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et de prendre en charge la scolarité des enfants. Ndaata sollicite un 11ème prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use:
purchase of cereals for re-sale

Achat pour revente

loans.name: Madronio

texts.en:
Madronio R. is married and has three sons; two are above 18 years old and both work in construction. The youngest is a girl who attends primary school.

Madronio runs a grocery store where he sells drinks, fruits and vegetables. Madronio’s wife is in charge of the grocery store while he travels door to door selling trifles in his town.

The grocery store is located in a strategic area near a crop of cotton. Since it is harvest time now, they have a huge demand and to supply this demand, they are requesting a loan to buy fruits, vegetables and drinks to sell in their grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase fruits, vegetables and drinks.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth F. is the owner of Na Zulma’s confectionary, located in Santa Rosa city. Ruth and her mother, Celestina Zarza, opened the candy shop five years ago. Since then the business has been running successfully because of the good quality of the shop's products. Everybody in her town knows about the delicious cakes and sweets that Ruth and Celestina make. Among the products they offer are wedding and birthday cakes.

There is huge demand for their cakes. This is why they are requesting a Kiva loan to buy more ingredients such as milk, chocolate and eggs to prepare the sweets

Ruth has two younger sisters who attend primary school. In their free time, they also help in the confectionary. The earnings generated by Na Zulma’s candy shop are the only source of income for the family. That money is invested in education and healthcare for the whole family.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients such as milk, chocolate and eggs.

loans.name: Pacajes Group

texts.es:
The association called “Pacajes” has been part of the family of “Pro-Mujer” for three years and they have successfully repaid seven loans. The association is part of the Juan Pablo II Center located in the Ferropetol Zone in El Alto City. They are 16 female members, which have proven to be very organized on their activities and responsible with their payments.

They are different businesses within the association for example; there is a meat market; one that makes and sells tents for cars; but the main activity is handcrafting metals. They make their art in shops located on their own homes, unfortunately they sell only on demand because they don’t have a place to show them to the public. This year they have their hopes set on showing their creations on the “Annual Craft and Micro-Entrepreneur Fair in La Paz” (FIPAZ), where they will be able to meet local and international customers.

They request a loan to be able to have capital to purchase new raw material and complete higher quality crafts. This would increase their income and they could improve the quality of life for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

La asociación denominada “Pacajes” pertenece a la familia de Pro-Mujer hace ya tres años cumpliendo con su séptimo ciclo de crédito. La mencionada asociación pertenece al centro focal de Juan Pablo II ubicada en la zona Ferropetrol de la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha cuenta con 16 socias que han demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito y actividades internas.

Existen diferentes negocios dentro la asociación como ser; la venta de carne vacuna, confección y venta de carpas para automóviles y otros, pero la actividad principal es Hojalatería (artesanía en hojalata ), obras que la realizan es sus talleres ubicados en sus propias casas y los venden únicamente a pedido, ya que no cuentan con un lugar para exponerlos, Este año tienen la esperanza de poder exhibir sus trabajos en la Feria anual de Artesanía Y Microempresa de la Ciudad de La Paz (FIPAZ) donde podrían encontrar mayores contactos de venta, incluso a nivel internacional.

Por eso solicitan mayores créditos con el fin de reforzar su capital para realizar obras de mejor calidad, con esto mejorarían sus ingresos, con el unico de objetivo de mejorar el estilo de vida de sus familias.

loans.use:
They need a loan to support their capital, purchase materials and export their creations.

Necesitan mayores creditos para reforzar su capital , comprar materia prima y exportar sus obras.

loans.name: Dieynaba

texts.fr:
Mrs. Dieynaba N. is a member of the village bank of Mbousnakh in Thies. She has already taken out 10 loans and repaid them without difficulty. She would like to expand her little cereals business by purchasing millet, peanuts, and niébé (a type of peas). Her income permits her to improve living conditions for her family. Dieynaba is requesting a loan which will be reimbursed in one single payment at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Dieynaba N., mariée est membre du banc villageois de Mbousnakh à Thiès. Elle a déjà bénéficié de 10 prêts remboursés sans difficulté. Elle veut renforcer son activité de commerce de céréales en achetant du mil, arachide et niébé. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Dieynaba sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use:
business selling foodstuffs

commerce alimentaire

loans.name: 17 De Agosto Group

texts.es:
In the city of El Alto, in the middle of the Andes, one finds the 17 de Agosto ("August 17") association, a group of 14 active members who have worked with Pro-Mujer for more than two years, showing themselves to be very organized and responsible in their joint activities.

Almost all of them, with their families, between costs for housing and other expenses, spend at least 400 Bs. per month, an amount that is very difficult for them to scrape together. Furthermore, they have to pay interest on loans that they received from Pro-Mujer to set up their businesses.

The businesses are diverse: making and selling lunches, for example, or making and selling blankets and "polleras" (a kind of skirt, traditionally worn in La Paz), but the sale of sports clothes is the main business. They generally take their products to La Paz's "Mananeras" market, so called because sales are only allowed until 10 in the morning ("manana"). They need more capital to buy raw materials so that they can expand their production and increase their revenues which, in turn, will provide them with greater economic stability.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

En la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra el centro focal Los Andes , a éste pertenece la asociación “17 de Agosto”, grupo formado por 14miembros activos, que trabajan junto a Pro-Mujer hace mas dos años, demostrando ser muy organizados y responsables en sus actividades de grupo.

Casi todas con sus familias por lo general entre gastos domésticos y gastos alquiler, de vivienda, mensualmente gastan 400 Bs. mínimos, monto que lo consiguen con mucha dificultad, además deben pagar sus cuotas de crédito que lo consiguen gracias a los negocios que emprendieron con la ayuda de Pro-Mujer.

Existen diversos negocios dentro la asociación, por ejemplo la elaboración y venta de almuerzos, confección de mantas y polleras (vestimenta típica de La Paz), pero la venta de confección de ropa deportiva es la actividad principal. Productos que generalmente los ofrecen en la feria de las “Mañaneras” de la calle Tumusla ( La Paz), denominada así ya que solo les permiten vender hasta las 10 de la mañana. Ellas Necesitan mayor capital, para comprar materia prima, así expandir su producción y generar mayores ingresos, de esta manera conseguir estabilidad económica en sus hogares.

loans.use: Buy raw materials.

loans.name: Dieuf Diarignou 1 Group

texts.fr:
