loans.name: Dativa

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 34 year-old Dativa G.. She is married, and has six children between the ages of 3 and 13. In 1999, Dativa opened her liquor store. Dativa has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and has applied for this loan in order to purchase additional stocks of beer and soda in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

This client is a perfect example of why microfinance works and why a large majority of clients repay their loans. A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or kiva.org) for the first time ask anxiously, “but how do you make sure people pay the loan back? Won’t they just take the money?” The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually the ‘poor’) are less trustworthy, efficient or educated than ‘ordinary’ people. Whether or not this is true is irrelevant for a number of reasons. Firstly, most microfinance lenders have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk. More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive: the incentive clients have to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another…The primary incentive is to have on-going access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 50 year-old Sarah M.. She is a widow and has three children aged 10, 20, and 30. In 2000, Sarah opened her general store and takeaway kiosk. Sarah now requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of soda, water, juice, oil, sugar, and soap in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or words in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness. (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, although I’m sure they’re working on it!) The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool. All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd. in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of water, soda, juice, cooking oil, soap, and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Hailing from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania is a 25 year-old woman named Maria M.. She is married and has no children. In 1999, Maria established her genge (grocery) business. Maria has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, flour, fruits and vegetables. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. This is the kind of place local people send their children to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal. In these situations, they usually do not have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice, flour, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is 38-years old and a married mother with three children. She has sold lingerie for both men and women in the local market for 10 years. She travels to Accra to buy her products and retails them for profit. She will use the loan to buy more lingerie and expand her operation. Monica is a member of the group called "Bo Bra Pa" meaning live a Good Life. Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy men's and women's under garment stock

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is married and he has two children. He has been selling baking flour, sugar, rice and other consumables with his wife in the local market for five years. Due to the demand for his products, he will use his loan to increase his inventory. This will increase his sales and enable him also make some income to take good care of his family. Emmanuel is a member of the group called “Bo bra Pa” meaning Live a Good Life. Members in the group agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan

loans.use: To buy more bags of flour, sugar, rice, etc

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a Sunday school teacher and also he sells ladies’ slippers and men’s shoes in the local market to earn a living. He is 27-years old and not married. He will use the loan to buy more slippers and shoes to expand his inventory. By working hard and with the help of this loan, he will be able to save money he needs to propel him to his desired dreams. He is a member of the group called “Adom Mmrodo” meaning Abundant Grace. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more ladies’ slippers and men’s shoes

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 41-years old and the mother of three children. She also has one adopted daughter who is currently in school. She sells slippers and babies’ dresses. There is the demand for children’s clothes and she will use her loan to increase her inventory and sales. Her previous loan from Sinapi helped a lot and she was able adopt a little girl to who needed a home. Joyce is a member of the group called “Adom Mmrodo” meaning Abundant Grace. Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan. Margaret in the photo with her adopted daughter.

loans.use: To buy more ladies slippers and children’s dresses.

Margaret will use her loan to increase inventory and sales. She hopes to start savings with this loan. Margaret is a member of the group called “Adom Mmrodo” meaning Abundant Grace. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increase inventory of grocery products

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 45-years old and a widow with 3 children. She has been selling rice, sugar and flour in the local market for 10 years. She will use her loan to increase her inventory and also to avoid price hikes in the products by buying in bulk. Cecilia is a member of the group called “Adom Mmorodo” meaning Abundant Grace. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice, sugar and flour

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Mambo (Hello!) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 37 year-old Stella L.. She is married and has four children between the ages of 1 and 11, plus one additional dependent.

In 2007, Stella established her meat and soft drink business. Stella has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now needs a new loan to buy beef and soft drinks in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool! All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To buy beef and soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Kwame

texts.en: Kwame is 45-years old and is married man with two children. He is in the same business as his wife. Many Ghanaian farmers use cutlass and hoes to farm during the farming or planting season, and  the demand for simple farm tools are very high. Kwame will use his loan to buy more cutlass and hoes to sell to farmers who need the tools to work. He is a member of the group called Believers. Members of the group agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy farm tools to sell to farmers

Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 39 year-old Naomi M.. She is married and has two children aged 13 and 22. In 2005, Naomi established her general store and salon business. Working seven days a week, and 13 to 16 hours a day, she earns about US $130 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband and two employees. Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your ow

Naomi requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, oil, bean, charcoal, haircare products, and wigs. loans.name: Tawopaneh Ll Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu F. is 42 years old and married with three children. She is the Tawopaneh group leader. She and Adama F. have been in the same savings and rotating club for two years and, as the loan size has grown bigger, they decided to guarantee each other's loan.

Kadiatu and Adama sell dry fish in Magburaka market. They would like to expand their businesses by becoming suppliers to the retailers in Magburaka town and the surrounding villages.

They are therefore requesting a loan of Le.2,000,000 ($US700) for that purpose.

loans.use: To purchase stock of fish.

loans.name: Bear Bozzu L Group

texts.en:
Abu K. is 28 years old and married with three children. He and the other member of his group, Mariatu K., sell dried fish in the outskirts of Magburak town. The two of them are the first Kiva clients in the district. With the previous loan, they were able to pay cash for the fish and purchase wholesale. They were able to make a good profit which enabled them to meet their children's school requirements for the semester.

Abu and Mariatu would like to expand their business and build up their own capital, and are therefore requesting a loan of Le.1,800,000 ($US625).

loans.use: To purchase stock of fish and transportation.

loans.name: Gara United Group

texts.en:
Mohamed T. is 36 years old and married with two children. With his previous loan from Kiva, Mohamed expanded his business by producing and selling tye and dye materials in addition to selling sewing supplies.

As a group leader, he was able to work with other members cooperatively and they were able to complete all their repayments on time.

Hawa Bangural owns a small grocery in the market and would like to expand the business. Mariatu S. sells fresh fish in the same market. She would like to increase her stock and build her own capital.

They are therefore requesting a loan of Le.4,000000 ($US1,200).

loans.use: To purchase clothing and sewing supplies, fish and groceries.

loans.name: Wara

texts.en:
Wara D. is 32 years old and married with three children. She started her grocery store three years ago and with her previous loan from SMT she increased her stock and has attracted many customers.

Wara would like to expand her business to generate more income to improve her family's life. She is therefore requesting a loan of Le.3,000,000 ($US1,050).

loans.use: To purchase various groceries for her store.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Isatu K. is 39 years old and married with five children. She has been running her clothing business for more than four years. With her previous loans, she expanded her business and started selling the materials wholesale to a few retailers in Makeni town. During this period, she advertised her products to clients in Freetown and now has many customers who would like to purchase the materials wholesale.

Isatu is requesting a loan of Le.3,500,000 ($US1,200) to increase her production. She would like to see her children through their education.

loans.use: Purchase cotton materials, dyes, caustic soda and starch.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is 35 years old and married with three children. He owns a phone accessories shop in Makeni town and has been in this business for three years. With his previous loans he diversified his business and acquired more training on business planning and management. He developed a business plan that needs capital of Le.3,480,000 ($US1,200) to increase his stock of cell phones.

loans.use: To purchase cell phones, SIM cards, phone cards and other accessories.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
Abibatu B. is 33 years old and married with a child. She is a professional nurse and her husband is a laboratory technician in one of the hospitals in Makeni town. With their meager salaries, they started a mini phamacy in the town, providing services to the community. They also purchased some medicines on credit in which the installments are paid on a daily basis. This did not enable Abibatu to make a good profit.

With news of the Kiva program going around the town, Abibatu approached SMT with a loan request of Le.2,500,000 ($US875) to purchase stock with cash and build her own capital.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of medicines.

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Aminata K. is very grateful to Kiva for her previous loan of $175. Because of that loan, Aminata can now purchase two baskets of dried fish at the same time and has increased her profit and capital. With the profit, Aminata purchased land to build a house for her family.

Aminata is a group leader. She and the other two members, Fatu I. and Marie T., have developed their savings and rotating club. They save some amount weekly to repay their installments.

Fatu and Marie are also engaged in fish selling. All the members would like to expand their business.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of dried fish.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama M. is 33 years old and married with two children. She owns a small general store in the town of Makeni. Her business income supports the family expenses, especially paying house rent.

Mariama would like to build a good future for her children, and is therefore requesting a loan of Le.3000000 ($US1,050) to expand her business and increase the family income.

loans.use: To purchase rice, onions, salt and other food items.

loans.name: Kida Pass United Group

texts.en:
Abdul K. owns a pharmacy in Magburaka town and has been running the business for more than eight years. Abdul is forty-five years old and married with four children who are all in school. With his previous loan of $175, he increased his stock and was able to purchase the medicines in cash.

Abdul and his fellow group member, Issa L., would like to increase their stock and build their own capital. They are therefore requesting a loan of Le.3000000 ($US800) for the purpose.

loans.use: Purchase more medicines for the pharmacies.

loans.name: Tamaraneh Ll Group

texts.en:
Issa K. is 40 years old and married with 5 children. He is the group leader and a Kiva client. With his previous loan, he built his capital and expanded his construction supply business. With this loan, he hopes to continue that expansion and increase his income.

The other member of the group, Henry C., owns a pharmacy in Magburaka town and would like to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase construction supplies to increase stock.

loans.name: Maroc Tailoring Group

texts.en:
Khalil K. is forty years old and married with four children. He is a Kiva client who received a loan of $175. With that loan he purchased fabrics, buttons and so on and earned a profit. With the profit, he embarked on tie-dye production and has diversified his business.

Khalil has customers from Freetown who purchase the materials and sell to middlemen from Liberia. He has good quality production and would like to use this loan to increase his production.

The other member of the group, Susan S., sells rice and peanuts. She would like also to expand her business.

The group is therefore requesting a loan of Le.2000000 ($US700).

loans.use: To purchase more sewing materials and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Hamidu

texts.en: Hamidu C. is fifty-two years old and married with six children. His business selling clothing and bags is the main source of income for the family. With six children all in schools, Hamidu needs to work hard to meet their school requirements. He is therefore requesting a loan of Le,700,000 ($US250) to help his business.

loans.use: To purchase more bags and clothes.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mrs. Seng Saroeun, 56, has operated a business selling food and grocery products since in Pilea Village, Prey Veng province, Cambodia. Each day, she can typically make about $3 (USD) in revenue. She is married with four children. One of her children is single and works as a driver; the other three are married and live outside the family’s home.

Seng Saroeun hopes to use this loan to purchase more grocery products to fulfill her blooming customer demand. With the various kinds of products, she has is providing more options for her customers. In the future, she will use her additional profit, along with another loan, to keep expanding her inventory so that she will be able make ends meet.

Her husband, who is employed by a local hospital, appears in the photograph, because Mrs. Seng Saroeun was not available.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products

loans.name: Min

texts.en:
Mrs. Min T., 49, a mother of seven children, works on her plot of farmland growing rice, vegetables, and fruit. She has been doing this for over 15 years and she can typically earn an average of $4 (USD) each day in revenue.

Her husband has worked as a mechanic in BathamBong province since 2001. He must live away from home for his job, but returns to the family home twice a month. One of her 7 children is employed by a garment factory, one sells mechanical tools, one is married and lives on his own, and the rest are unemployed.

After learning about CREIDIT from one of her neighbors, Min T. has applied for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase a hand-tractor to plow her farm and to help with other farming work.

loans.use: To purcahse a hand-tractor to plow her farmland.

loans.name: Seab

texts.en:
Mrs. Seab C., 27, is married with two children and works for a garment factory, earning about $2.60 each day. Her husband has been working as a construction foreman since 2000, earning around $6 of net income each day.

To commute to work each day, she and her husband have to use a motor-taxi service, which costs them more than $1.50 per day. This is double what it had been in the past, because of the very high inflation rate in Cambodia. To reduce this expense, Seab C. and her husband would like to take a loan from KIVA to purchase a motorbike to use for their family’s transportation. This will be an asset to her and her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to use for the family's transportation

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey P. is 32 years old and is working hard to grow rice day by day. She has been a rice farmer since 1999. She and her husband earn a combined daily income of $3 USD. The couple has two children who are both too young to attend school. They hope to be able to afford to send their children to school as their income becomes more stable.

Rice farming is a crucial profession in Cambodia. However, many farmers are selling their land and giving up traditional farming as big business pours into Cambodia looking for land to develop. As a result, rice crops are becoming smaller and smaller, causing a food shortage in the region. Thus, Srey P.’s profession is a crucial one.

She wants to dig a large basin by her field that she can use to store water for irrigation. This will save her money. Eventually, she hopes to branch out into raising pigs, as well.

loans.use: To dig an irrigation po d

loans.name: Abduvosit

texts.en:
Abduvosit F. is 34 years old. Abduvosit is married, and he has two adorable kids. His wife maintains their house on a daily basis and takes care of their children. In order to support his family, Abduvosit sells household goods such as kettles, pails, basins, and other such items, and he has been in this business for the past 15 years. With this experience, Abduvosit is able to choose goods that meet the requirements of his customers, whose tastes differ greatly. His business is quite successful and generates a stable income, which allows Abduvosit to improve his family's living conditions over time and to make his kids happy. 
During the past 3 years, Abduvosit has been provided with several loans through IMON, and he has proven himself to be a trusted client with his positive credit history. Now, Abduvosit is requesting a loan in the amount of $600 for a 5-month term. With the loan proceeds, he is planning to purchase new merchandise so that his clients have a wider range of products from which to choose when they make their purchases. He asks you to be an important part of the growth of his business by offering your support.

loans.use: By purchasing additional household goods in order to expand his business' inventory and to thereby provide his customers with additional products to choose from

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in silver jewelry and women's clothing.

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
Akram P. is an unmarried, 22-year-old farmer. In his farming operation, he grows rice, wheat, peas, and pods, and he has been cultivating the land as such for the past four years. Each year, Akram grows a sufficient amount of crops for his family's consumption needs and to sell crops for a profit as well. In fact, by generating a stable income from this business, Akram is able to support his parents. Akram’s mother, who is pictured in the photo, helps him to sell his crop yield.

This year is especially important for Akram as he is going to marry his chosen one. With this purpose in mind, he is seeking to increase his business in order to make enough money to pay for his marriage. Thus, today he requests a loan in the amount of 3,000 Somoni ($875), to be repaid within 7 months, in order to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. Akram thanks everyone for supporting him, and he promises to be punctual with his loan payments.

loans.use: To generate additional income in order to pay for his marriage by increasing his crop yield through the purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long S. is 45 years of age. She sells traditional Khmer noodles from her roadside shop in Siem Reap province. She does fairly well, earning $5 USD per day of profit.

Her husband, Sek Saren, is a construction worker. Construction work is readily available in a developing province like Siem Reap, which draws over a million tourists each year. He earns $7 USD per day. They have a somewhat large family with five children. Two of the older kids are already employed, one as a teacher, and another as a construction worker alongside his father.

Long S. wants to take out a loan to buy rice in bulk, which she will then resell. Rice prices are currently high and she thinks this will be a reliable source of extra money.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy women's clothing in bulk to replenish her stock and increase her sales volume.

loans.name: Zarnigor

texts.en:
Zarnigor D. is a 27-year-old, unmarried woman, living with her parents. Zarnigor is a shop vendor, and has operated her own small business for 4 years already. She rents the shop in the local market, where she sells personal hygiene products such as detergents, soaps, toothpastes, razors, and deodorants, as well as different kinds of toys for kids and other such items. On a typical day, she works from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. Because Zarnigor is very friendly and polite, she has developed an extremely loyal client base. 
She dreams of expanding her business and of opening up her own store. To that end, she is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,400 Somoni ($425) to purchase more goods to sell and to thereby increase the variety of products for her customers' benefit. Zarnigor promises to repay the loan within 9 months, and thanks everybody for their support.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional goods in order to diversify her product line

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy costume jewelry for a small business.

loans.name: Fotima

texts.en:
Fotima S. is 49 years old. She is married with five children. Her husband is a taxi driver. In order to help her husband support their family, Fotima runs her own business.

In particular, Fotima has been running a catering business for 25 years, whereby she provides the meals of the national cuisine. She operates her business with the help of her daughter in the central local market, which allows Fotima to have many clients, the majority of whom make purchases in the market and stop by her business to enjoy her delicacies. On a daily basis, Fotima purchases the latest foodstuffs and she then cooks delicious dishes for her customers.

Over the last 25 years, her business has generated stable income, but this year is especially important for Fotima because one of her sons is getting married while another son is graduating from school and will soon be entering the university. Being a loving mother, Fotima wants to support her sons and, in order to do so, she is planning to expand her business by purchasing additional kitchen wares. If she is able to put her plan into place, she expects to generate more income, which she will spend on the marriage of her oldest son and to pay the fees for the education of her younger son. With this purpose in mind, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $850 to be repaid within 12 months. Fotima is counting on your help, and not only thanks all for supporting her but also promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To expand her business and to satisfy her customers' demands by purchasing additional kitchen wares

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in a location for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy shoes and underwear for her business

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen B., wife of M., has been living in the city named Vehari, Pakistan for the last 20 years. She has two sons. Waqas is 18-years-old and due to family circumstances, he has only been educated through the fifth level of school. The second son, Nouman, 15, is in the 9th level.

M. drives his own rickshaw which was purchased through a previous loan. Waqas helps his father in his work. They are requesting a new loan to repair the body of the auto-rickshaw.

Parveen B. is the leader of her group. Mussarat B. would use the loan for agriculture. Kosar B. would buy a rickshaw. Kalsoom B. wants to buy a sewing machine and Shahnaz B. wants the money to start a cloth business.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand and start businesses, repair a rickshaw and purchase a sewing machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in costume jewelry and underwear.

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
Akram K. is a 28-year-old married man. He has two kids, both of whom are young at present, but he works extremely hard in order to ensure the best future for them. His wife takes care of their house and watches over their kids.

For a living, Akram works as a farmer, and he has done so for six years. His business is stable and is the main source of income for his family. Specifically, Akram grows onions and maize. During the growing season, Akram works in the field from early in the morning until late at night. Five years ago, Akram started his business by producing onions on a meager 0.10 hectare plot of land, whereas now he grows onions and other vegetables on a 1.30 hectacre plot.

Today, Akram is requesting a loan in the amount of 2,000 Somoni ($600) to be repaid over 12 months so that he may purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. In addition, any remaining loan proceeds will be used to pay the salaries of his hired seasonal workers. Akram thanks everyone for their support, and he promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchasing seeds and fertilizer, and to pay the salaries of his seasonal workers.

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida B., wife of M. H., is a mother of three children: two sons and a daughter. The two sons attend school and the daughter is not yet old enough. Her husband drives a rickshaw which was purchased through a previous loan. She is requesting a loan to buy one more auto rickshaw to increase the family's income and repay the loan with any profit.

The other group members have other needs for a loan. Kosar B. would use the money to repair her rickshaw. Rani B. wants a loan to buy a rubbing stone machine. Najma B. would expand her utensils business and Shamsa B. would expand her milk business.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand businesses, purchase a rickshaw, repair a rickshaw and purchase a rubbing stone machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Shavkat

texts.en:
Shavkat K. is 33 years old. He is married (his wife's name is Umriniso), and he is the father of 4 children.

Shavkat works hard on the farm, along with Umriniso, in order to make his children happy and to provide them with a good education. In his farming operation, he grows and sells crops such as tomatoes, onions, potatoes, cucumbers, carrots, apricots, peaches, and apples.

With the onset of the sowing season, he is planning to sow onions, potatoes, and carrots, which is why he is seeking a loan. In particular, he is requesting a loan in the amount of 2,000 Somoni ($600), to be repaid within 12 months, in order to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds. After gathering his yield, he wants to sell them to local inhabitants at prices that are lower than in the market. He promises to repay the loan in a timely manner. Shavkat and his hopeful wife are counting on your help, and he expresses his deep gratitude to everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: To take advantage of the upcoming season by purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer and to thereafter sell his fruits and vegetables in the market for affordable prices

loans.name: Ghafooran's Group

texts.en:
Ghafooran B., wife of M., is a mother of two sons. She successfully repaid a previous loan which she used to purchase a sewing machine and stitch clothes for neighbors. Her daily income is three to five dollars. Her husband is a trader by profession. She would like a second loan for her husband to expand his trading business.

The other members of the group have various needs for the loan. Zahooran B. wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. Nargis B. wants the money to change the body of auto rickshaw. Sajida B. wants a loan to start a dental clinic and Nargis B. wants a loan to expand her clinic.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand businesses, repair a rickshaw and purchase a donkey cart.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Adolat

texts.en:
Adolat K. is 58 years old. She is married, and she and her husband have raised eight children. Almost all of their children are married and have their own children, who in turn adore their grandparents.

Adolat is a farmer. She has worked in agriculture for twenty years, and in that time she has gained a great deal of experience and a love for the land. Her younger sons, who are not married, help her with the business. In particular, Adolat grows crops such as potatoes, onions, tomatoes, cucumbers, and carrots. She and her sons work from early in the morning (typically starting at 6:00 a.m.) until late in the evening (until 6:00 p.m or so). Each year Adolat grows a sufficient amount of crops for family consumption and to sell for a profit. Indeed, her business has been the main source of stable income for the family for the past five years because her husband is retired and is on a pension.

Adolat is planning to cover the higher education expenses of her youngest son because he is finishing school and will soon be entering university. As such, she is seeking a loan in the amount of 2,000 Somoni ($600) to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer for the harvest and to thereby increase the quality and quantiy of her yield. The loan will be repaid within 12 months. Your support will truly help her and will be an important driver of the growth of Adolat’s business.

loans.use: To cover her children's education costs by purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer in order to facilitate a better harvest

loans.name: Maqsoodan's Group

texts.en:
Maqsooda B., wife of A. G., is a mother of two children, a daughter and a son. Maqsooda B. would like to give her children a better education than she can currently afford. Her husband has a cattle business and she is requesting a loan for her husband so that he is able to buy cattle and increase the family income.

Other members of the group have other needs for the loan. Samina B. would like money to repair her van. Sharifan B. wants a loan to expand her medicine business and Hanifan B. would use the loan to expand her cloth business.

The funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase cattle, expand existing businesses and repair a vehicle

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sabohat

texts.en:
Sabohat M. is a 32-year-old widow living with her parents. In order to support her parents over the last 10 years, she has been running her own business. In fact, her business is very successful and generates stable, significant income, thereby allowing Sabohat to improve her family's living conditions.

More specifically, Sabohat sells fruits and vegetables, such as tomatoes, cucumbers, apricots, strawberries, and apples. She begins her workday early each day at 5:00 a.m., and she buys fruits and vegetables from local farmers and thereafter sells such produce in the market. Importantly, she sells her goods at attractive (i.e., reasonable) prices, so her business is popular amongst shoppers at the market.

Currently, she is seeking to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables in order to increase the variety of goods she sells. Consequently, she is hereby requesting 2,400 Somoni ($700) to be repaid within 12 months. Sabohat is counting on your help, and she wants to express her gratitude for everyone who supports her.

loans.use: To diversify the products she offers for sale by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat P. is 37 years old. She is married with four children, all of whom are in school except for her oldest son, who is in his freshman year of university. As any mother, she wants her children to have everything they need, and she dreams that all of them will be able to receive higher education.

She and her husband are both farmers. She has been working the land for six years. In fact, she began cultivating her land through her and her oldest son’s efforts, and she has gradually gotten ahead in life with such efforts. On the cultivated land, Muhabbat grows wheat, rice, and maize. When it is prime growing season, Muhabbat works in the field from early morning until late at night. She is proud to say that her business is one of her greatest accomplishments in life.

Muhabbat is planning to cover the higher education expenses of her second son because he is soon finishing school and is about to enter university. Therefore, Muhabbat is applying for a loan for the first time, seeking 2,000 Somoni ($600) over a term of 12 months. With the loan proceeds, Muhabbat is planning to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer, and she use the remaining proceeds to pay the salaries of her hired seasonal workers. Muhabbat thanks everyone who trusted her and for their support, and she promises to pay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To pay for her children's higher education fees by purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer, and by using the remaining loan proceeds to pay the salaries of her seasonal workers

loans.name: Vazira

texts.en:
P. Vazira is 44 years old. She is married with three children. Two of her children attend the university and the third one is finishing school but will soon attend the university as well. Her husband is a cook in the local restaurant.

In the picture Vazira and her friend Ibodat are trading alongside on another, that is why they have been pictured together. Vazira is standing on the left side and Ibodat is on the right. Vazira is a market vendor. She started her business ten years ago with only a few products, but her business is currently more stable. Vazira sells fruits and vegetables, such as apricots, apples, strawberries, tomatoes, cucumbers, and many others. Her sons help Vazira with the business. Vazira begins her workday early each morning at 5:00 a.m. In practice, she buys fruits and vegetables from the local farmers, and she then sells such produce in the market, where she is well-known by customers for her friendliness and because she sells her fruits and vegetables for affordable prices. As a result, Vazira’s business generates a stable yet considerable income for her family.

Now is the prime season in which to sell fruits and vegetables, and her goods are (not surprisingly) in high demand. For this reason, she is seeking to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables in order to re-stock her store and to thereby expand her business. Accordingly, she is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500 Somoni ($450), which she will repay in 8 months. In turn, she hopes to generate additional income in order to pay for her children’s university fees and, with your help, this will be possible. Vazira would like to thank everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: To expand her business in order to pay for her children's university fees by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.en:
Kahramon R. is 64 years old. He is married with six children, one of whom is still under his care. The rest of his children are married and have their own families and children, who adore their grandparents. He loves his children and grandchildren very much and does his best in order to make them happy and to provide them with a good education.

As such, Kahramon runs a farm, where he grows wheat, rice, and different kinds of vegetables, depending on the season. In fact, he has worked in agriculture for twenty years, and in that time he has gained a tremendous amount of experience and a love for the land. His two oldest sons help him with the business, which is stable and generates the main source of income for the family.

At the same time, the business requires a lot of effort and money to sustain the business. Currently, it is the prime season to work the farm, so Kahramon wants to grow wheat, potatoes, tomatoes, and cucumbers. Accordingly, Kahramon is seeking 1,000 Somoni ($300), to be repaid within 12 months, to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. Kahramon thanks all for supporting him, and he promises to pay back his loan within the allotted time.

loans.use: To take advantage of the prime growing season by purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Ibodat

texts.en:
Ibodat S. is a 45-year-old market vendor. She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. Her husband is currently unemployed, which is why her business is the main source of income for her family.

At the picture Ibodat and her friend Vazira are trading alongside one another, that is why they have been pictured together. Ibodat is standing to the right side and Vazira to the left. As previously stated, Ibodat is a market vendor. Indeed, for more than ten years, she has been selling fruits and vegetables, including apricots, apples, strawberries, tomatoes, and cucumbers, in the central local market. Her oldest son helps Ibodat with the business. Ibodat begins her workday early each morning at 5:00 a.m. In practice, she buys vegetables and fruits from the local farmers, and she then sells such produce in the market, where she is well-known among the local shoppers because of her friendliness and the fact that she sells her fruits and vegetables for reasonable prices. Accordingly, Ibodat’s business generates a stable, considerable income for her family.

Now, it is the prime season in which to sell fruits and vegetables, and (not surprisingly) her goods are in great demand. In addition, she wants to expand her business in order to generate even greater income to cover the higher education expenses that her darling children will soon need. For this reason, she is planning to purchase more fresh fruits and vegetables to sell in the market, and in order to do so she is seeking a loan in the amount of 1,500 Somoni ($450), to be repaid within 8 months. She asks that you lend your support to a dedicated mother so that she can make her children’s dreams a reality because, with your help, this will be possible.

loans.use: To capitalize on an increase in demand by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela A. is a 32-year-old mother of five children. Pamela and her husband live in Kisumu, Kenya. Pamela has taken and successfully repaid three microfinance loans from KMET.

She began selling clothing door-to-door in 1999 and has since expanded her business. She currently rents the shop seen in this picture in which she sells clothes-making materials, shoes, purses, ties and other clothing items. She also employs a full-time tailor to meet her customers’ demands. Pamela is a community health worker trained in home-based care by KMET. She is, thus, well-known within her community for her health-care work. In addition, the central location of her shop and her many years of doing good business within the community has gained her a good reputation and a wide customer base.

Her business has done quite well due to the added advantage of access to loan funds; she has combined the additional money with hard work and perseverance in order to increase her stock and materials and build a successful income-generating business. Pamela is proud of her accomplishments and that she is now able to contribute to paying household expenses. She requires US $800 to increase her stock of ready-made supplies to keep up with the growing demand.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Increase stock of ready-made clothes.

loans.name: Vart

texts.en: Vart S. raises pigs for a living at her home in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is 40 years old and a devoted mother to her only child, who she is currently putting through school. She earns about $2 USD per day in her current line of work. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver earning $5 USD per day. She wants to invest her in own business raising pigs by purchasing a few more pigs to use in breeding, as well as to buy pig feed in bulk.

loans.use: To buy pigs and fooder

loans.name: In

texts.en:
Mrs. In S., 53, is a mother of four children who lives in a part of Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. She and her husband run a stand that recharges home batteries for the people in her community. There are many houses in her community that still have no any electricity, so the people in that area use a home battery to generate electricity. When the batteries run out, they have to come over to Mrs. In S. to ask for recharging.

With this business activity, In S. and her husband can typically earn at least $4 each day in revenue. They have now requested for a loan to purchase a machine to use for recharging batteries. With the new machine, she and her husband can recharge more batteries each day.

loans.use: To puchase a machine that recharges batteries

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea C. is 39 years old and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a tailor, working out of her home each day sewing traditional Khmer clothing and making additions and repairs to older clothing. She earns $2 USD per day. Her husband is a government official in the local office. These positions are often grossly underpaid, as evidenced by the $2 USD he earns per day.

Even with their meager salaries, the couple supports five children. The oldest works as a motor-taxi driver to support his family, also earning $2 USD per day on average. They need to develop additional sources of income if they are to continue to support their large family. Even dual incomes are rarely enough to support families in poorer countries like Cambodia.

Lea C. would like to buy a motorbike for her second oldest son to operate as a taxi, adding to the family income.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to operate as a taxi

loans.name: Vorng

texts.en:
Vorng P. is 45 years of age and sells Khmer style noodles, in the form of a traditional soup, from her roadside stall. She is relatively new to the business, having only started it two years ago and is earning $2 USD per day. Her husband is a construction worker. Unfortunately, his work is transient, taking him from village to village throughout the province, and often keeping him away from his family.

They have a total of eight children. Five of these children are still in school, an impressive feat for a large, poor family like their own. Two of the children are old enough to work and add an additional $4 USD per day to the family income. One of their sons wants to start working part-time as a motor-taxi driver to do his part to help. Vorng P. would like to be able to better provide for her family by buying a motorbike for him to use.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to use as a taxi

loans.name: Pi

texts.en:
Pi T. is 28 years old and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a young housewife with only one child to take care of, along with her elderly mother. She and her mother do limited farming, as well, from a small rice field by their house. However, this is purely to provide for their sustenance. Her husband is a construction worker earning $3 USD per day. This work is somewhat unreliable and seasonal.

Pi T. wants to look into developing their rice field and increasing production by buying a cow to plow larger fields. Once they have developed this business, they will have their fields to fall back on even when construction work is scarce.

loans.use: To buy a cow for plowing

loans.name: Lek

texts.en:
Siem Reap is a province in northwestern Cambodia, on the shores of the Tonle Sap Lake. The provincial capital is Siem Reap. Most of the people living in Siem Reap are farmers and some work selling souvenirs and others operate small restaurants.

Lek S. lives in Siem Reap and supports his family by making drums from palm tress and selling them at the market. He earns approximately $7.50 per day. Mr. Lek would like a loan to purchase more palm trees to make drums. This will allow him to make more money to support his family in the future.

Mr. Lek's wife, Tem Chean, works by selling firewood to the local villagers, earning around $2.50 in profits per day. The couple has two children, one of whom is a student.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services to both rural and urban communities in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase more palm trees to make drums

loans.name: Eoeun

texts.en:
Eoeun S. is 45 years old and lives in the central province of Siem Reap, Cambodia. She is the devoted mother of six children, working hard each day so they can attend school, despite being relatively poor. She sells fish in the crowded provincial market, competing with many other vendors each day to make her sales. Her husband is a fisherman and gets up early to secure the day's catch. Together they earn about $5 USD per day working as a team.

Although fishing is their primary source of income, the couple feels they need to invest in a side business to provide a better life for their children. They now want to start raising pigs from home. They will sell these pigs periodically to the butcher for profit.

Her husband is pictured here, because Eoeun S. was not available to be photographed.

loans.use: To buy pigs.

loans.name: Choeum

texts.en:
Choeum S. is 49 years old and is living in Siem Reap province. She is a widow, still working the farm that she and her husband first bought together. Her earnings are meager, coming to $1 USD per day on average.

She has three children, one of who was recently married. The two unmarried children attend school and still live with her. They try to help her with the farm in their spare time. Her oldest daughter works her own farm, while her husband is a construction worker. They also help to support her as best they can.

Choeum S. is very grateful for her son-in-law’s support and wants to help him specialize as a carpenter in his construction business. Her loan will go to buying him much-needed tools, which will make him a much more valuable asset to his employers.

The picture shows her daughter, becausae Choeum S. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To buy construction tools.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Siem Reap is one of major tourist attractions in Cambodia. Most people support their families by farming and, but some must have additional business to support the family.

Sam A., age 41, is one of a hundred groceries vendors who set up shop in front their houses in Siem Reap. On average, she makes about $5 of profit per day. Her husband is a police officer and his salary is only $35 a month. They have seven children. Two are married and live away from home and three others are students and sometimes help their mother by selling groceries after school.

To meet her customer’s demand, she would like a loan to by more groceries to sell in her store. This will allow her to save for the future and to pay for her children to go to the university. She will use any remaining profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell in her store

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en:
Choeun S. is 45 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province in Cambodia. She sells chickens in the meat section of her local market. She has been developing her store for some time now, and has had her business since 1998. Her husband also deals in animal sales; he sells cows that he purchases throughout the area. Together, they earn approximately $6 USD per day.

The couple has six children, all of whom attend school. A few will graduate soon and begin looking for work. Choeun recognizes the potential earning power of her two businesses and wants to invest by buying young cows and chickens to boost sales.

loans.use: To buy cows and chickens.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Saom Sovanna and her husband, Lim H., live in Siem Reap province in Cambodia with their two children. She is 29 years old and works selling groceries in a busy market, where she earns around $25 in revenue each day. Her husband, aged 33, has been a farmer since 1998. On average, he makes less than one dollar per day.

Since the market price of rice is good, Lim would like to purchase another plot of farmland to grow more rice to sell. (Saom Sovanna is pictured with two children.)

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Thirty-year-old Man M. lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She has a unique business selling lotus flowers and has been doing so since 1999. The lotus is an important cultural symbol in Khmer culture and has even influenced much of their architecture. She earns $5 US per day selling this special flower. Tep Kan, her husband, is a provincial farmer. He earns less than $1 US per day doing back-breaking work in the rice fields. They have six children, and proudly have seen two of them married. Three of the remaining children are students, and one is now a construction worker. Man M. cares for her children’s futures and she wants to see her son obtain more and more jobs in construction work (which is often a freelance profession). She hopes to purchase a small motorbike that he can use for his commutes.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Eoeum

texts.en: Eoeum S. is 45 years old. She sells traditional Khmer cakes earning $4 US per day from her home in Siem Reap province. These cakes include ingredients such as rice, banana, and coconut. Her husband works at a nearby rice farm. They have three children. One young child stays at home, but the older two must work. They are waiters at a restaurant, each of them earning $2 US per day. Eoeum wants to take out a large loan to repair her house in anticipation of the upcoming rainy season. Monsoons often flood and destroy smaller Khmer homes and she knows she cannot afford to lose her place of business as well as her family's shelter and home.

loans.use: To buy wood.

loans.name: Thouen

texts.en: Thouen N., 27 years old, is a housewife and resides in Siem Reap where her two children are students. She stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her family. Her husband,Tem Sokhon, who is 29, is a motorbike mechanic and earns approximately $3 US per day. At home they care for an elderly father. To earn more money, Thouen plans to purchase a plot of land near the school to open a small stand to sell groceries.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land near the school and open a small stand to sell groceries.

loans.name: Chet

texts.en: Chet R. is 41 years of age and works as a farmer in Siem Reap Province. She and her husband, Leng Ren, have had their farm since 1980 when the Vietnamese occupied Cambodia. Even together, they only earn $2.50 US per day. The couple has five children, one of whom is married. The younger children are all students, except for one who is developing his trade as a motorbike mechanic. Chet R. recognizes her son’s trade as potentially beneficial for the family and wants to buy him a good set of mechanics' tools to use. She also wants to buy a pig to raise on the family farm.

loans.use: To buy a pig and to buy mechanical tools.

loans.name: Roth

texts.en: Roth A., 64, is a mother of two children and is a widow. She started her own business selling various kinds of fruits at a market over ten years ago. She can typically net around $2 US each day. One of her children is a garment factory worker, making about $4 US each day. The other child is unemployed. Roth A. is requesting a loan to expand her inventory by purchasing a greater variety of fruits to meet her customer demand. With the remainder of the loan she will purchase a motorbike for her son to operate a taxi business to transport passengers from place to place.

loans.use: To expand her fruit inventory and to buy a motorbike for her son to operate a taxi business.

loans.name: Eao

texts.en: Eao P. is 48 years of age. She runs a small grocery store out of the front of her home in Siem Reap Province. This is not uncommon as most Khmer homes are actually built with the expectation that the front will become a store. She does quite well, receiving business from all around her district. She earns $10 US per day in revenue or total sales. Her husband, Chem Seoun, raises pigs and earns significantly less at $3 US per day. Both of them work from home where they can often see their nine children. As of right now, five of the kids still go to school every day. One of the older children is a semi-truck driver. Eao P. has been working on a business plan with her son to start a trucking business that will transport sand and dirt to construction sites. All they need is the start-up capital to buy the truck!

loans.use: To buy a truck.

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Chuon T. is 35 years old and owns her own grocery store in Siem Reap province. Rural Khmers often set up small grocery stores outside their homes to turn small profits during the day. However, Chuon T. and her husband run a full-fledged food and produce stall at their local market. Working there together, they earn about $5 US per day. She supports all four of her children while they study in public school on this income. She knows she has something unique with the good location of her store and growing client base. Chuon hopes to expand her inventory drastically and to buy certain items in bulk.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk.

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Bùi Thị Hải is 55 years old. She joined TYM in 2002. She is a hard working, nimble person. Since the beginning, she has discussed with her husband about investing in farming livestock. Before joining TYM fund, they used to raise only one pig running with the purpose of not to waste leftover food from their meals. With the fund from TYM, they have built new pig pen and take it seriously as a business. They have pigs for breeding and pigs for meat. They also raise chickens and ducks. Her family situation has improved a lot compared to before. Today, beside farming livestock, they also trade "cau". She is able to buy all the goods for her household and a car. Her family income is 3.000.000 VND a month. She is requesting a loan of 10.000.000 VND to be invested in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Bùi Thị Hải, năm nay 55 tuổi tham gia Quỹ Tình Th¬ương năm 2002. là người phụ nữ chịu thương chịu khó, nhanh nhẹn, ngay từ những ngày đầu tham gia vào Quỹ, chị đã bàn bạc với chồng mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi. Trước đây khi chưa có vốn gia đình chị chỉ nuôi 1 con lợn với mục đích khỏi lãng phí những thức ăn thừa của gia đình. khi tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn, gia đình chị đã mở rộng chuồng trại và việc chăn nuôi quy mô hơn, nuôi lợn nái và lợn thịt, ngoài ra chị cùng chồng bàn bạc nuôi thêm gà, vịt. Mạnh giạn làm theo suy nghĩ đó gia đình chị đã khá lên rất nhiều so với trước. Hiện nay ngoài việc chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn đầu tư thêm vốn vào buôn cau, việc buôn bán cau cũng rất thuận tiện bởi vì đó là một mặt hàng không thể thiếu trong mỗi gia đình người Việt Nam khi có công việc.Với việc vay vốn phát triển kinh tế gia đình chị đã mua sắm được nhiều trang thiết bị cần thiết phục vụ cho gia đình, ti vi, xe máy ....Thu nhập bình quân 3.000.000đ/ tháng.Vòng vốn tiếp theo gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư dự án.

loans.use: buy pigs, chikens and food for them

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy K. is 48 years old and has been farming her rice fields in Siem Reap province since 1980. Her husband, Saom Kean, works day to day beside her as they struggle to raise their children. Together they can earn only $2.50 US per day on average. They have seven children, three of whom are already married. Only one child is still in school, and the other three who remain unmarried farm with their parents. For poor farmers, children serve as a kind of guarantee or security. When Soy K. is too old to work she wants to have built a business her children can continue and that also allows them to take care of her. Her loan will go towards buying a small tractor which she will use to plow her farmland each season; she will also be able to leave this investment to her children, who will continue to work as farmers. Soy also has plans to expand into livestock once she can afford the pigs. She is pictured here with a neighbor's pig.

loans.use: To buy a tractor.

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long M. is 24 years old and lives in Siem Reap province. She sells produce and various food products outside a local Buddhist temple. Long reports doing quite well, actually earning $50 US on a good day! This puts her at the top of her trade easily, earning much more than the average grocery store owner. One of the reasons for her success is high sales to people who buy offerings for the temple each day. Her husband is also a hard worker, doing electrical and mechanical work on cars. He earns about $5 US per day. The young couple has one child, who is too young to attend school. Long M. wants a loan to invest in her already quite successful business; she will further boost her inventory to respond to customer demand.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products.

loans.name: Kum

texts.en: Kum H. is a 35-year-old housewife in Siem Reap province. Her husband, Mom Moeun, is 36 years old and sells firewood to support his family. He does relatively well selling something that every family needs in order to cook food, earning $15 US per day. They have five children. Three of the kids are in school, while the older two are souvenir salesmen near the province's historic temples. Their earnings are crucial to the family, adding another $15 US per day. Kum H. wants to boost her husband’s already successful business by purchasing a motorbike for him to use in transporting the firewood each day from place to place.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Ear

texts.en: Ear L. lives and works in Siem Reap province, home to a large area known as the Tongle Sap river basin where fishing is a vital part of the provincial economy. Ear, 27 years old, raises pigs and earns about $2.50 US per day; her husband is a fish seller at a local market and earns about $5 US per day. They have one child who is too young to attend school. Selling fish has been a stable source of income for the family; however, it is a business with much competition. Ear's husband must go to the market early every morning to sell his fish while they are still fresh; after selling the fish, he has no work for the remainder of the day. She wants to buy him a motorbike he can use as a taxi once he leaves the market each day. Ear is pictured here with the motorbike they hope to buy.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Puch

texts.en: Puch Y. is a 40-year-old housewife in the province of Siem Reap. She depends on her husband, Vun Pat, to provide for her and for their three children who still live at home; Vun's business is recharging batteries. These large batteries (similar to car batteries) are used to power lights in places with no electricity. He earns the equivalent of $4 US per day. The family actually has six children, but three of them are married and live outside the family home. The oldest child living at home is a construction worker and contributes to the family income. Puch Y. recently came into possession of some farmland, but needs cows to plow it. Once it has been plowed, she and her older children will plant their first rice crop. If they can produce food for themselves, their cost of living will decrease, allowing them to save money in other areas. (Mr. Vun Pat is pictured because his wife is not available)

loans.use: To buy two cows.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Rosemary Birungi’S Group

texts.en:
Rosemary B. is a 42-year-old single mother of three children, aged 22, 18, and 14. They are all in school. For the past 15 years, she has been selling bitenge, large pieces of fabric with colorful prints on them used by Ugandans to make clothing of all kinds. She buys 40 or 50 bitenge at a time from importers at 20,000/= each (Ugandan shillings, about $12 US), and sells them at 25,000/=. She sells bitenge from her home, but also takes them to big offices or “everywhere she can find customers.” Although sales vary, she says that she usually sells between 20 and 30 bitenge a week, and on payday, can sell them all in one day.

She has been a member of MCDT for about six years and has received over 10 loans. With this loan, Rosemary can increase her business by stocking more high-quality bitenge to sell. It will also help her to pay for the basic necessities for her family: school fees, rent, food, and medicine.

loans.use: To sustain her business and meet personal needs

loans.name: Betty Katutu’S Group

texts.en:
Betty K. is a 52-year-old widow with six children ranging in age from 30 to 18. Her husband died in 2000, but even before that, she had her own business selling bitenge, fabric printed with colourful patterns that are tailored and worn by people all over Uganda.

She sells bitenge from her home, buying them from people who import them from Congo for 10,000/= (Ugandan shillings, about $6) each and selling them for 15,000-20,000/=. When she gets the money, she buys about 50 at a time to keep in stock, an inventory that she usually sells in about two weeks. She likes this business, she says, because “it doesn’t give her a headache,” allowing her time for church and to look after her children.

She joined MCDT in 2004 which provided the capital to increase her investment in her business. This will be her eleventh loan. With a new loan, she will add to her inventory of bitenge. “It helps me a lot to survive in the city.”

loans.use: Increase inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Grace Ddamba’S Group

texts.en:
Grace D. is a 30-year-old married mother of five children. She has been a member of MCDT for the past four years. For the past eight years, she has run a shop where she sells sodas and juice, with sodas being the best sellers. Passion fruit juice is also popular. In her shop, she has two refrigerators so people can buy cold sodas.

Grace and her group have received multiple loans in the past, which she says have helped her keep her children consistently in school. With a new loan, she will be able to add on to her business. Currently, at the end of the day, she is sold out. With a loan, she will be able to keep more beverages in stock so she can sell more drinks each day and make the business more profitable.

Ultimately, her goals are to build a house and to help her children go on to university. In the meantime, the loan helps her to take care of all her day-to-day needs.

loans.use: To increase beverages in stock to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kyosiga Women's Group

texts.en:
M. Joyce, 50, is the chairperson of the Kyosiga Women’s group in Kayunga. She is both a farmer and a business woman, selling ladies' clothes (mostly underclothes) to women in their offices, hospitals, schools and homes as a side business since 1990. Joyce buys her inventory from Kampala, mostly on Thursdays and Mondays every week.

As a farmer, Joyce grows beans, potatoes, and cassava and sells her crops to tenders, who supply this food to schools and usually pay her each week. At times when the season is not favorable for her, Joyce buys crops from fellow farmers and then supplies them to her customers. She has enough land for this farming and employs laborers to quicken the work. She is married with three grown children and she cares for 8 grandchildren at home.

Joyce needs a loan to buy dried beans for sale. She will share the loan with the 14 other members of her group.

loans.use: To purchase dried beans for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Muwerere, Kyosiga Group

texts.en:
M. Edward has a retail shop that has been running since 1991. He is 31 years and is married with 3 children. He cares for his relatives, including his wife's parents and his in the village.  He would like a loan to help him buy more goods like sugar, cooking oil, soap, rice, and maize flour for his shop.  Since he buys in small quantities, he usually buys the goods from Nazigo and Kayunga. 
His dream is to transform his shop into a wholesale business in a few years to come and, with this change, he will be able to buy in large quantities from Jinja, where the prices are much lower than in Kayunga and Nazigo, though transport is slightly high. In the shop, he is helped by his wife and together they are determined to make their dream come true.
M. Edward has been a good member of Kyosiga women’s group for one and a half years and he will share the loan with the 10 other members of the group.

loans.use: Muwerere Edward plans to buy sugar, cooking oil, soap, rice, and maize flour so as to increase his shop inventory.

loans.name: Hugo

texts.en:
Hugo M. is 38 years old and is married to Mirian Rodríguez. The couple has three school-age daughters. In 1993 Hugo opened a store in a well-known market in the city of San Lorenzo. Today he owns three different stores in the market.

The money provided by the credit will be used for the purchase of winter clothes as well as shoes.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve her workshop and buy more materials for sewing

loans.name: Otilia

texts.en:
Otilia I. is a 39-year-old woman who is married to Hugo Morel. The couple has two sons.

Ten years ago, Otilia opened a fish store located in the well-known market of San Lorenzo city. She sells different types of fish while her husband owns a small grocery store in their own house where he sells food and drinks.

Part of the money provided by the credit will be invested in the purchase of fish and the other part in merchandise for the grocery store such as rice, sugar, pasta, drinks, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of fish and merchandise such as rice, pasta, oil, drinks.

loans.name: Mafumu, Kyosiga Group

texts.en:
M. James is a teacher by profession, teaching at Mubanda Primary School in Kayunga. He is 36 years old and is married with four children, all in school, in addition to 2 orphans that belong to his late brother.

The income of a primary school teacher in his locality is not sufficient for all the necessities in his home and so James started buying and selling coffee beans. He buys dried coffee beans from farmers and takes them to the coffee factory for removal of the husks. Customers are usually at the factory ready to buy. He uses the husks for manure on his farm but he can also sell off the excess. James also buys fresh coffee beans from farmers and dries them at home, thereby lowering his costs. He also books orders from those coffee plantations that are yet to be ready by paying a deposit to the owners. This business has allowed him to support his family and to buy pigs and chickens for his wife to keep at home for their farm.

James is a good client of Pearl Microfinancing in the Kyosiga Women’s group, making his repayments promptly. Now he needs a loan to buy more coffee seeds. He employs workers to move around on bicycles to the villages to purchase the coffee beans, but at times they are not fast because of the hills and his dream is to buy a motorcycle to make the process much easier.

loans.use: To increase an inventory of coffee beans.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Miguel

texts.en:
Miguel A. is 43-year-old man married to Modesta Narváez. The couple has two young sons. He owns a despensa (grocery store) located in their house. In rural areas in Paraguay, the despensas could be considered as a meeting point, where people not only buy products but also gather and gossip. That is why is despensas are a very profitable business in those areas.

Miguel always tries to offer a wide variety and quantity of products for a lower price. After a lot of effort he bought a car, which allowed him to start a delivery service. He dreams of having an autoservice store and competing with the big supermarkets.

The money provided by the credit will be used for the purchase of meat, bread, milk, cheese, and other items.

loans.use: Purchase of milk, cheese, bread, meat, rice, sugar, and others

loans.name: Teofilo

texts.en:
Teofilo is a 55-year-old man who is married and has three sons. Each of them has their own family and business. Teofilo works with his wife in his store where he sells electric materials such as cable wires, light bulbs, etc. The store is located in a strategic place on the main street, which is a very crowded area.

Thanks to Teofilo’s entrepreneurial ideas, he could bring many benefits to his entire family.

The money provided by the credit will be invested in merchandise such as cable wires, light bulbs, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of cable wires, light bulbs, etc.

loans.name: Mpagi, Kyosiga Group

texts.en: M. Godfrey, 30, has a "boda boda" (a term used for the motorcycle business in Kayunga). He is married with four children, all in school, and he looks after orphans belonging to his late brother. Godfrey purchased his small "Mate" motorcycle second hand one year ago.   It has been giving him a hard time, and now he needs a loan to fix his motorcycle’s engine. His dream is to buy a new and much bigger motorcycle called "TVS" or "Bajaj." He believes that as long as he is still in his lending group, Kyosiga, he will achieve his dream.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle engine.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nalwoga, Kyosiga Group

texts.en:
N. Edisa has a stall where she sells cabbage, pineapples, tomatoes, onions, carrots, spices and so much more. She lives in Kisoga and she has been a member of her group, Kyosiga, since its inception.

Edisa is a widow with five children from 4 to 14 years of age, all in school, and she pays their school fees single-handedly with the help of loans. She now has another baby who is provided for by its father. Edisa buys her goods from farmers in the villages. With the loan, she intends to buy more vegetables and fruit for sale.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and spices for sale.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo Rolon has two school age sons with Martha Benitez.

Today, Bernando is taking care of the children alone since Martha went to Spain in order to find a job and thus earn more money. Paraguayans tend to emigrate from Paraguay to countries such as Spain and Argentina in order to produce more income. According to these people, there is no another solution than migration, because they do not find jobs in our country. Remittances are a very important source of income for the whole country.

Bernardo owns a grocery store. In rural areas in Paraguay, the Despensas could be considered as a meeting point, where people not only buy products but also gather and gossip. That is why is Despensas are a very profitable business in those areas.

The money provided by the credit will be used for the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, pasta, drinks, etc.

loans.use: The money provided by the credit will be used for the purchase of rice, sugar, oli, pasta, dirnks, etc.

loans.name: Rose Wamala’S Group

texts.en:
Rose W. is a 50-year-old married mother of three children, the youngest of whom is 16. She has been a member of MCDT for four years and has received nine loans in the past.

She owns a retail shop in Kampala where she sells various staples such as sugar, rice, oil, maize flour (posho), and millet. The business is profitable, though the profit is small. Still, the profit helps the family to pay for school fees and food and to help them improve their life and their future.

She will use a new loan to buy inventory for the shop and to add new items. It will also help her to deal with the current price increases for food items.

loans.use: Add new inventory

loans.name: Crescencia

texts.en:
Cresencia P. is a fifty-year-old woman who is married to Patrocinio Rejala. The couple has two sons.

Cresencia used to sell fruits and vegetables as a door-to-door salesperson while her husband used to sell cloths in the same way. After many years of effort, they saved some money and built their own house. In addition, the couple decided to invest a portion of the money saved to open a grocery store in their house so Cresencia could stay at home with their children and at the same time take care of their business.

The couple wants to buy a car. The automobile will make their work a lot easier.

The money provided will be used for the purchase of flour, rice, oil, rice, meat, sugar etc.

loans.use: Purchase of flour, rice, oil, rice, meat, sugar etc.

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
N. Juma has been a farmer for 20 years, growing maize, beans, cassava and coffee and raising cattle for their meat. He recently also began a "boda boda" (motorcycle taxi) business. He is married with 8 children, of whom 6 are in school. He also cares for five orphans who stay with his mother.

This is Juma's second time to ask for a loan from Pearl Microfinance through the Kyosiga Women’s group and the first loan was paid promptly. He needs a loan to buy a cow for its meat.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Kisaakye Women's Group

texts.en:
N. Fatuma, 37, is the chairperson of Kisaakye Women’s group in Rubaga. She is a widow with three children aged 14, 12 and 8 years. She also looks after her sister’s one-and-a-half year old twin daughters who were disowned by their father.

Fatuma has been selling used clothes--mostly T-Shirts--for men, women and children for 13 years at the Owino market, on Rubaga road, and at daily local markets known as “mubuulo.” So far she has been buying one bale of clothes at a time, but her dream is to buy 5 bales in a day if she could get the necessary capital for it. Right now she needs a loan to buy another bale of clothes because most of her funds have been spent on school fees now that the children are reporting for school.

loans.use: To increase an inventory of used clothes.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia M. is a 39-year-old woman who is divorced and has two daughters.

Lidia is a door-to-door salesperson who offers clothes and shoes. She is a lovely person and is well-known in her town. That is her biggest advantage: since she is very nice and famous, the number of clients is very large. In addition, she offers different type of payments to her clients.

The money provided by the credit will be used for the purchase of merchandise such as sport shoes and clothes. In the future, she plans to buy a car in order to transport her merchandise. An automobile will make her work a lot easier.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes: t-shirts, pants, and sport shoes.

loans.name: Mirian

texts.en:
Mirian is married to Rogelio and the couple has a three-year-old boy.
